29, 2014
Early Access Review
								The year is 2015, and the world teeters on the brink of war. Radical ultrafeminists have seized power on the internet. Their goal: the establishment of the tumblr empire. Kotaku, Rock Paper Shotgun, Polygon, one by one the nearby independent communities slip back into the tumblr fold. tumblr Transliving Deadkin sit in the Rapeland Mountains and the Transethnic Forests, poised to strike to the south and east. The world holds its breath, and waits. For one small group of elite soldiers, the war has already begun. The Patriarchy Special Forces Group, Man Battalion, Ableist Company, deployed on peacekeeping duty to the Republic of Triggering in the Rapelands. This handful of Supreme Gentlemen represents the very tip of the phallus, the first line of defense. Equipped with the latest battlefield technology, and trained in the latest techniques of opressive warfare, they strike swiftly, silently, invisibly. They call themselves "the Mysogynists."In this game, "TOM CLANCY'S 7 DAYS 2 DIE" you do battle with severely mentally disturbed users of a website known as Tumblr, whom believe themselves to be reanimated corpses with an endless hunger for living/male flesh.  Your only hope for saving the world is to fight your way through the nigh endless hordes of pretend-dead-people, and sever the head of their organization in the Synagogue of Degeneracy, Patricia Hernandez, and thus closing shut the jaws of Oblivion, forever.

								Slightly Addictive gameplay?? with nearly 1200 hours under my belt I'd say yes indeed.The game just keep's getting better but never losing what makes it addictive, the constant work towards something better, with the constant fear of loss.The fully destructable world and the voxel building and crafting put it a step ahead of ARK : Srvival and the like, because you can build whatever you like, trenches, bases, defenses, it's not predefined like it is in games like ARK.It's LEGO, you craft block by block.The new RPG Skills and Perk tree really do a great job in fleshing out your character and brings skill benefits for working together in a small group with specialists, you can still play solo, you just need to be a little more frugal with your skill points spending.Lots of servers out there, hugly active multiplayer, building your own server is pretty easy if yo udont like the way others are set up.AAA+++ for the Fun Pimps, they keep working on this little gem of a game and the love and care shines through.Follow Joel on the dev diary here http://joelhuenink.tumblr.com/

Early Access Review
								Alpha 13 has taken away and messed up a lot of aspects of this game that I loved, but I still recommend it because it's still fun.But I want the old forges back (where you poured iron/brass/glass/etc into a mold of an object and got that object instead of feeding a forge resources and having it poop back out whatever you want if it has the right tools attached to it). I want different types of meat back, as another reviewer said. Bear stew, venison stew, rabbit stew having different benefit levels? Loved it! I don't like the new UI very much and I feel like crafting has been ruined. The old display of food/water status above health and stamina was great! Why take that out? The server I play on has it modded back in and I'm grateful for that.The skill system is... really kind of ridiculous. Alpha 9 was the most fun I've ever had in a survival/crafting game. It was simple enough yet complex enough. I liked how crap fell on the ground when you cut trees or broke stones instead of just flooding into my inventory. I do like the new zombies but the "assemble" crafting system for weapons/power tools irritates me to no end, as does the fact that I can no longer make molds for gun components and make them at my forge. What happened, guys? I'm really holding out hope for A14.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've played quite a few zombie survival games and even non-zombie survival games, and the one game that rises above them all, alpha stage or not, is 7 Days to Die.  While it does, at times, get a tad on the boring side still traversing the map looking for points of interest and taking several in game hours to find them, and while it does get a tad monotonous finding the same 2-4 houses time and time again, everything else pretty much falls into place.Don't get me wrong, every alpha game has it's glitches and bugs, and that's why it's alpha, but you don't see 7 Days to Die "starting over" like some other games out there *cough rust cough*, or being only playable enough to craft about 5 things and that's it.  There are only two alpha games I have ever bought where I did not regret it, and that is this one, and Factorio. (check it out via google. It's not on Steam.)  Now on to specifics.First, environment. More specifically, audio. For me, I always choose to play with music off, so I can't comment on any music, however I do remember the 7 Days to Die menu theme to be prety catchy. I will say that this is the ONLY game I have ever played where I have literally jumped or felt actual fear when playing. Some people have felt that while playing F.E.A.R., Slenderman, or other games, but I really didn't. This one however, when I am looting a house, and I hear snarling, drooling, barking, vomiting, groaing, screaming, breaking wood, breaking glass, breaking concrete, and metal being hit, all at the same time, and I can turn around and not tell where all the sounds are coming from, it gets pretty scary.  And let me tell you, when you can't get inside somewhere safe at night and those zombies and dogs are running at you and you can barely see, that, my friend, is pretty darn terrifying. I don't get scared by much, The Fun Pimps do a good elicting the fear emotion out of me when playing this game.I do love the "AHA" moments of the random generaed maps now as well when I DO discover new things. Like the first time I discovered twin factories, I stood in amazement and thought of all the wonderful things to do with it. I tried making a base out of it but discovered it was much too large to defend alone, but it sure was fun trying.  Or the first time I discovered a non-center city on the map, or got my final magnum part. Those were pretty cool moments for me.  Sure, one could turn on creative mode and just give yourself those things, but that takes the fun out of it when you are working together with 4-5 other people and you are the first on your server to craft a magnum, or to find a factory, or something like that. Those moments happen for everyone.  The zombie pathing and A.I. is a bit glitchy, but they are fixing that soon in 9.2, so I won't talk much about that, but it is annoying.  There are little weird things like destroying cement ramps outside of a parking garage and getting wood planks as a result, or being able to plant trees on roads. Nothing major, but still there.Graphically, this game is amazing. I only started playing about 2 days before 9.0, so I never saw the game personally when it was more cubed, but what I saw in videos, the smoothing of the world is a big step up. I never knew this was a voxel game until I read it. Playstyle is great, I wouldn't change a thing, Crafting is also great. There are so many things you can make, but I do feel there should be a few more things, such as the medicine cabinet, wall safe, and wall lights. I think those should be craftable. Maybe they will be in a future patch, I don't know.I don't know much more to say, other than all I really see are improvements from the makers, and they continue to do so. I haven't seen anything about adding fishing to the game, so I hope that is a plan at some point. Maybe it was a future stretch goal that didn't get met.UPDATED REVIEW: Alpha 13.8: I STILL highly recommend this game. It keeps getting better and better. Sure there are new bugs and still some old ones, but the developer team is small so they can only do so much. And it's still Alpha, so you are basically testing the game while playing.The new UI and Crafting system is great in my opinion. I see a lot of people with 1000+ hours say they hate A13, that it ruined the game and would no longer recommend it, but I am of the opposite. A13, IMO, made the game better. And A14 is around the corner and is going to have perks, an introductory quest, and much needed fixes and optimizations. You CANNOT go wrong buying this game, and as of this edit, it is HALF OFF!

Early Access Review
								If you like zombie games more sandboxy, if you also liked the idea of minecraft and others like it but hated the oldschool look and feel then you'll like this. I mostly play on scavenger as it suits my laid back attitude, but if your a hardcore nutter then max out the settings and see how long you live for. You can play multiplayer or single (I prefer single mode) and the game has a whole lotta things you can fiddle with to get the type of game you want. Gather supplies, build stuff or just tunnel underground and pray, you play how you like which is epic imo. Even though it's in the early stages and thus changing at times (sometimes needin a good tweek) it's good fun I have have no regrets buying into, it unlike a few other greenlight games I've bought.A14 and all I can say is from epic to more epic, when this game hits release in the future it will set a new standard, even at this early stage it is an awesome blend of survival/crafting/rpg elements. I only play single player and lan with my wife and I have not had a game that has so many options or different ways to play it. You should be warned though, the game has two sides to it, first you must learn to survive the enviroment and then there's the z's, both will try to kill you, good luck.

content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Holy Crap. This game gives credence to the theory "any game is more fun with zombies in it." -- it's basically minecraft in a zombie apocalypse, and it is FUN. You basically use the daytime hours to scrounge, explore, pursue your goals, and find safe haven (while the zombies are slower and less numerous) and use the night hours (when you'll need stealth and luck to survive for even a minute outside) fortifying your position, crafting what you've scavenged into things you need, and monitoring your defenses from the tireless predations of the dead. Complex crafting system that allows you to dismantle/reverse-engineer or build nearly anything you can find in the game. ALL TERRAIN completely deformable, by you, friends/foes, and the undead. I've played NUMEROUS campaigns and they have all ended in one of two ways -- crushed under the unrelenting hordes, or completely organically and spontaneously finding and making an awesome enclave that grew out of the circumstances I happened upon. Crafting, Fighting, Forging, Farming, Terraforming -- it's all there and it's all fun. AND THE GAME IS ONLY IN ALPHA! More content added all the time, (as of this date 3/2/14)

content:
er 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Review for 7 Days to DieI'm going to write this review based on version 10.3 (29'th of december 2014) - 7 Days to Die continues to impress with ever increasing patches and fixes coming from the development team. I must admit i was fearing for this game to turn out like the crappy Day Z or something like that, but the way this game has turned out is truly remarkable. It is so good i even bought a copy for my younger brother just to support the development team. Why is it good you ask? Well, the game contains key features regarding the freeworld, survival, RPG genres, which for example is interactive wellness needs (food, water, medication etc.) and extremely detailed building recipes and such, example: you cut down a tree, create planks, create wooden frame, fortify wooden frame, reinforces = zombie proof. This might sound like a lot of micromanagement but i assure you, it is not. You are always active while playing this game, always looking for ways to get better guns or better resources to fortify your magnificent Fort Knox of Reinforced concrete with a 100 meter deep trench......... With some wooden spikes in the bottom of course. In short, most amazing game ever with the greatest potential i have witnessed. Sorry for the long post steam-community here is a little song to cheer you up: 


YouTube™ Video: Preview - 7 Days to Die 

			Views: 13		

			prismGN.enjin.com

y 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								This's like dayz, you have to survive againt the weather, players and zombies while you hunt and harvest to have your own food. But here you also may construct your own house/base in blocks (relax the game is not in blocks), watchout contruct your base before the 7º day or you will see what is difficulty. The beginning may be a bit hard for beginners so I will give some tips, about the weather, well, don't go to the snow before you have your own clothes specially a good sweater and stay away from water or you will freeze faster in this biome (use stones to make a bonfire and wood to ignite), about the desert use light clothes and if you find water jump into to refresh before you lose health.In the beginning you can make your "clothes" using plant fiber or cotton and construct a "stone axe" using plant fiber, wood and stone and this is what will help you to take more woods and stones to construct your stuffs, you may also contruct a shovel that you will use to cave some clay (you may recognize it by the orange earth on the ground while you walk or even in the map) and contruct a furnace to make some iron burning some metal and finally progress in your game. There is a lot of thing to learn but I can't write everything here, just discover by yourself, this is the fun, oh and be sure you will die a lot, good luck.I just love survival games and this one impressed me a lot.10/10

content:
er 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was iffy about buying this game because the last early-access software I bought failed to deliver.  This game, however, is definitely proving worth the cost.  It's only in Alpha 9.3 as of this writing, but it's already better quality than many "finished" games I've seen.I think the best way to describe the feel of this game is to walk you through a brief chapter of my most recent game.  I found a building made out of stone, and decided that it would be a good place to try to fortify.  An overhang on the second floor blocked line-of-sight to the front of the door for anyone standing on top of the house.  I knew that was a major weakness; once the zombies get to the door, I would have no way of killing them without losing my last line of defence.  I decide to try to use the cinderblocks that are lying all around to construct another wall around the house, built in such a way that I can shoot down on the zombies trying to break through it.  Less than an eighth of the way through building my wall, I look up and can't even see the end of the line of zombies coming at me.My weapons are limited.  I have a crossbow, but it reloads so slowly that I'll only be able to take down three or so zombies before they get to me.  My sledgehammer can kill a zombie with one well-placed strike, but going into melee range with a horde that side would be suicide.  I've got about 100 rounds for a handgun, it's my only choice.  Taking careful aim to ensure headshots, I take down a half-dozen zombies.  More and more keep coming; I retreat up to the balcony.  I know that once the zombies get under the balcony, I won't be able to stop them from reaching me on the porch, but I reinforced the door, so I should be safe for a minute or two.  I try to pick off as many zombies as I can before they can hide under the balcony.  Once the end of the horde arrived, I knew that about ten have made it to the door.  I go downstairs to see how the door's holding up.  Luckily for me, the zombies aren't organized.  Some are trying to break down the windows, some are going for the door.  None of them have gotten a full breach yet.  I return to the balcony, trying to see if I can take down a few more before the wall is breached.  Some of the zombies notice me up top, and try to destroy a support column for the balcony.    This leaves them in a vulerable position, I take a few more down.  I hear breaking glass.  Trying to line up another shot, I fall off of the balcony.  There's still six zombies left, and they're all headed straight for me.  I open fire on them while backpedaling, hoping that there aren't more undead behind me.With the carnage over, I repair the ground floor.  Night is coming soon, and I won't be able to finish the perimeter walls before sunset.  Time to see if I can cobble together the last part I need to build a shotgun.  If a horde visits me tonight, that Beretta won't save me.

content:
y 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alpha Build Review as of November 2016: It's still awesome.7D has a ton of content especially for an alpha. Compare it to other alphas like back when Minecraft was in alpha, and the quality is also notable. Few crashes in my 100 hours of play, biggest technical issue I have is a greatly variable framerate, on a GTX 970 still dipping to 20fps at times.Overall, people might say it's a Minecraft/DayZ... and it pretty much is, but in the good way. A challenge to scavenge, a variety of changing, persistent PVE as time goes on, and a fairly hefty crafting system that mimics Minecraft's simplicity-crafting-grid type scenario. The voxel system is a neat physics addition compared to most builders, I'd say this plays as a more realistic, harder Minecraft, but with a wide variety of game settings to tailor to your playstyles, a great addition.If you like the builder-survival-crafting type games, I'd say this is one of the best at the moment, with a real reason to team up, especially on a public server, and not a total PVP deathmatch-with-zombies like DayZ or H1Z1. Can't say it's the most amazing of course, but I definitely enjoy my time with it and will hope they keep fleshing out the bugs and PVE side of things.

content:
2
Early Access Review
								I was given this game for free, friend bought it for me. Had a lot of fun playing it with friends. We pretty much played it every day, and are still playing it now (with a good MOD). Considering the fact that the game has been charging people money and has been on early access for over 3 years, without mods, the game can feel noticeably incomplete. Animations are buggy, which sucks when you have to land a head shot, zombies can spaz out, spin around like a top, or glitch through the floor or wall. Large parts of terrain can just disappear, you can fall through the world, chests bug out - not allowing you to open them, needing you to exit and reload the world. All in all, it is also very poorly optimized - runs poorlyLook I had fun with the game, that is very important, but I can't recommend buying this. You guys need to respect yourselves. If you buy games like these, and they do well - eventually we will be deluged with promising and perpetually unfinished products. We don't buy hopes and dreams, we should be buying finished games.Buy this game in another 3 years, maybe then. IF you want to give money away to a charity, who am I to stop you? But I really don't like these kinds of practices. I'm going to guess that this game will be in EA forever.EDIT:Processor Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790 CPU@3.60GHz 3.60 GHzInstalled memory (RAM) 8.00 GBSystem Type: 64-bit Operating System, x64-based processorNVIDIA GeForce GTX 760

number of helpful: 15 of 23 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a great, great game I would HIGHLY reccomend, even at it's original alpha price of 35$ Now that it's 25$ if you like the concept of Dayz minecraft just make the jump and get it, you won't be dissapointed.   I have bought Dayz, Rust and this, and while I like them all Dayz has been uninstalled. I like playing Rust a lot right now, but creatively I think this game takes the cake. I have always been entranced with the survival genre, and multiplayer games, especially games that encourage players to collaborate creatively. Rust is a more of a post apocolyptic survival game. Rust isn't a kos nightmare frenzy like Dayz is because you do get the ability to stash things and create bases, but as of right now pvp is the more mid-game/end-game goal as everything else becomes fairly easy once you get to know the mechanics. Rust (like Alpha Dayz) relys on the pvp to define the gaming exerience, and it basically turns into a fps where you want to loot cool pvp gear from other people. Just like Dayz. (Not bashing on it I am loving it right now.)  7 Days to Die however is a different creation and an entirely unique game. It is truly a zombie survival sandbox, that can be enjoyed greatly without even going online. The Zombie AI is great, even in its Alpha phase. Even slow walking zombies have a way of creeping up on you without you knowing until the last second, or filling into a house blocking the exits as you are checking food cabinets, forcing you to jump through a window.  I think the coolest thing about the game is that it is not just one game. You truly create the experience that you want to play. The Default (as you have probably heard) is that during daytime there are slow walking zombies, and at nighttime they turn into fast zombies. Extremely fast frenzied zombies that only slow down in the prescence of enough light (campfires, torches, ect.) The zombies will claw through any material to get to you. How long it takes for them to claw through a material depends on how durable that material is (stone is stronger than wood, which is clearly stronger than dirt.) A mudhut would be taken down in seconds at night time. Just being outside at nighttime in default is terrifying, encouraging a kind of forage and basebuilding during daytime, and fortifying and repairing your base at night time. You can change pages of settings, and even more in depth settings not in the actual game to craft the game that you want, choosing how many zombies spawn, if they are always walkers, or always runners, how much damage they do, or you do and many, many more options. I never really could get into minecraft because while I loved the concept, I felt no immersion. I felt that the game focused more on the creativity, than the survival immersion, but not only am I not good drawing or art, let alone 3D art, but the 3D art that I could create was in my opinion not terribly interesting, or at least not pleasing to look at. This game is all about immersion, and the graphics are incalcuably better than minecraft (and constantly getting better.) Still the physics are solid and sound, and to me incredible. Every piece of the game world is some sort of resource that you can mine and collect. Every inch of dirt is diggable and obtainable. Every stone that you see can be picked up and crafted into stone "blocks" (They are starting to replace classic minecraft blocks with "smooth terrain" something that ironically in the present state I find less smooth and easy to work with than the original block style, but I am sure that will be refined and corrected.) The reward of simply surviving is one very satisfying, yet incredibly hard goal, but really the sky is the limit. Jump on a friendly server and I am constantly shocked by the imagination these people have. They will have turned a warehouse into a castle surrounded by landmines and trenches with spikes on the bottom of them. Go into the castle and it is just a decoy, and ladders plummet deep, deep down into the earth where there is an entire underground world, with many rooms, undergound rivers, mines, bedrooms, lounges and tunnels. Above ground there are towers that lead to large gardens growing many different vegetables and fruit. There is a sandbox "God" or "Cheat" mode where you can spawn any item or resource that you want at any time allowing you to create anything you can dream up.  My first online experience was on a new server when the game had just came out, and a bunch of us found a huge town where we intended to stay together. We did the first night and ended up blowing a staircase away as zombies flooded into the house, shooting them as they tried to jump up the destroyed staircase. We somehow survived and looted the town the next day, but I got seperated and nighttime fell before I could find them and I was trapped in a small shack with one other person and no good defensive resources. Needless to say we were destroyed. My next online game we were in the ruins of a town full of large half destroyed buildings, many floors high, but basically trapped with hordes of zombies below us. I could go on forever but I will end this with saying if you are on the fence look at the patch notes. Out of all of the Alphas, these developers seem to be the most dedicated and hardworking developers intent on providing us with amazing gameplay rather than just trying to let the community make our own gameplay. Every month a miriad of changed occur making the systems more complex and in depth and adding new systems. The map gets larger and larger, even though eventually they will let us create our own maps and create random map generators. The graphics got a huge overhaul in the last build. In the last build we have got a working stealth and cooking system, as well as the beginning of an armor system. These developers are dedicated to making a truly great game with great AI, and it really is refreshing. It is to me a really good example of how gameplay is more important than graphics, something that tends to be forgotten in this day and age. And the graphics aren't bad.

content:
ry 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Spawned in rainy snow biome, made full clothes then got wet. This led to stage 2 hypothermia that drained my stamina until I was mauled by a horde.Spawned in the same biome 3 miles away from where I died and this time I stood on my camp fire. Five real time minutes later, I finally stopped having hypothermia, but was still too cold to go get more fuel. Horde found my camp and chased me off. I soon froze.I was able to escape the snow, but ran into a city where a fat police spit at me. Was getting wet the entire time. Chased into the snow again and had the second situation happen and died.By this time I had so little max health that anything could take me out. Got stunned by a lumberjack horde and died.The run I was able to make a base, the game practically forced one style of building or else your base will crumble and all the above will happen to you over and over again.Also, you need a dedicated server to play on, meaning you need to configure your network settings and spend at least an hour setting things up to have all the above happen to your merry band of survivors. Or you could buy a server from a third party hosting service. Or you could use the game's abyssmal "Survival MP" function that breaks every few in game days and forces you to reset your progress.TL;DR This game is another example of wasted potential, While it has good concepts, it's too difficult early on, forcing players to die numerous times before giving up, and looking up how to work around the game's numerous unbalances and glitches. Ask yourself this, how much crap are you willing to look past?(For the record, I was actually able to configure my own network to create an actual private dedicated server, but the program I used apparently was abandoned and no longer works. IMO, it's not worth it to wrestle with my network and the game again to get another server running.)

number of helpful: 28 of 48 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
24, 2016
Early Access Review
								A year ago, I would have recommended this game highly. I spent hours and hours building bases, crafting weapons, surviving hordes, and the ambiance of the game was so well crafted I found myself having nightmares about getting overrun by zombies.But Alpha 13 was a bad start and Alpha 14 has just made the game downright unplayable. I think they've focused so much on securing deals with Telltale, they've lost focus on delivering a quality experience to their original gamers.Here are my complaints:1) the weather system is ridiculously illogical - I've been in heatstroke during a snowstorm. As a player, you will spend nearly all your time just searching for water and drinking red tea. This is not hyperbole - in a 24 hour day, I spend about 16 hours just trying to keep myself hydrated.2) while the graphics have improved dramatically, the bugs they've introduced are horrible. Zombies randomly clip through walls. Hornets spawn an endless stream of zombies so hordes several days.3) it's become a grinding-based game just trying to accumulate enough materials to build and maintain a base. Exploration isn't all that possible now unless you play the game fully-nomadic, in which case, you desperately need a minibike and loads of gas so you can simply outrun the bugged hordes.4) quests and skills weren't thought out well. They're there just to be there, not because they add any value to the game experience.5) on any difficulty above Scavenger, due to the spawning bugs, the game becomes impossible to survive as the weapon balancing has been readjusted so your guns are virtually useless vs. the literal hundreds of zombies that will come your way.I really, really wish they'd focus less on the aesthetics and understand that gameplay is more than appearance.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								From my first try I was hooked on 7 Days to Die.  I missed the Kickstarter for this game, unfortunately, picking it up on the advice of a trusted Youtube Letsplayer at the stage of Alpha 1, and thought, wow this is for me.    From its very early stage of development this game was fully and excitingly playable, and somehow you could tell it had legs.  This game was exciting, realistic, fully working with my PC spec. and totally absorbing.  Blocky graphics didnt matter;  I loved the  way everything but everything is destructable and craftable.  Many have said this is DayZ meets Minecraft, and that is true in all the good ways.  Building your own base, finding ways to keep hordes out, farming your own crops and killing your food after the post apocalypse world is looted out was a challenge, taxing and deeply satisfying.  Its not enough to dig a hole in the dirt and wait for sunrise; Zombies in this game are worthy opponents.  You will NOT survive if you are out at night, or if your base is weak - these undead are fast, scary, loud and deadly.  Running away is not an option. Then as the long awaited Alpha 2 came out... everything got better and some things got even harder to survive.  Then further updates, more challenges, better graphics, sophisticated crafting tools, this is the gift of a game that keeps on giving.  Just as you thought you had it sussed, new zombie types were introduced, tougher landscapes, zombies that could smell you, hear you, sense you, hunt you.  But its not all in their favour, we now have stealth, smooth terrain, craftable guns, repairable weapons, it just keeps on getting better with each update, and slight (non gamebreaking) bugs are fixed every week and released every friday, so that for a YouTuber like me                                    (  https://www.youtube.com/my_videos?o=U  ) its hard to keep up with the stuff the Fun Pimps roll out.Practically every aspect of the game is adaptable to your level and your enjoyment.  You can play on their default settings or you can make it harder if you like Hard Core, or easier if you want to relax and choose less stress.  Want more loot? fine.  What fewer zombies? fine,  longer days and shorter nights? choose your ratio.  Want Airdrops of supplies? you got it.  Tailor the game just how you like it.  Singleplayer is great, Multiplayer is there if you want company, PvE or PvP, all are available.  The smooth terrain now makes it less like Minecraft or DayZ -  those days of that comparison are over.I believe that any Survivalist (the name we give ourselves in this game) will tell you there have been times when all of us have said "Darn, thats a bug, but hey - its Alpha, right?"   None of the minor problems along the way to Alpha 8.3 (at time of writing this review) have made the game unplayable,  7 Days to Die in Alpha is better than most games on full and final release, better than I could possibly have expected and worth much more than I paid for it. I fully recommend this game at whatever stage you come on board.  More bang for your buck - definitely.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Why This Alpha Game Is Worth Paying For..Reviewing a Z game nowadays almost seems played out but I feel this one is necessary due to the current amount of them available.Since L4D released in '09 the Z craze has definitely infected the gaming community. Fast forward to now~I've recently played DayZ, Infestation, Dead Linger, Contagion, and now 7D2D...A few noticable difference that stand out:1. 7D2D is very playable in it's current state with a highly interactive Dev team. 2. Everthing in the world is destructable and usually provides resources.3. Your toon can jump!4. The world is persistent offline and online which means your structures and mines stay there until destroyed.5. Crafting System!! <<-- This is one of my favorite aspiects and I cannot  WAIT until they add more recipes!!6. Construction. That's right you can build the zombie survivor base you've always dreamed about.7. Miining.  Mining ores then crafting items. Mining with explosives! +108. High scaleability of server configuration settings which gives complete control of the game environment.9. Hunting and Cooking!! <<--Venison stew anyone? Maybe a blueberry pie..10. Farming. Rooftop Farming FTW!! +1011. Zombies! As many or as few as you like, depending on game settings.      a. Zombies Never Run = 0 or 1     b. Zombies Always Run = 0 or 1     c. Zombies Only Run At Night = 0 or 1     d. Zombie Agression = 1-5     e. Zombie memory time? 60 - 180 seconds     f. Zombies are lootable!12. Character XP/Level system is there but not functional, yet..13. Mod support and toolkit for modeling/worldbuilding and custom scriptingHopefully, this review was helpful for you, I'd like you to spend your money on the right game the first time.I'm sure the others will mature to some great things, but this game is FUN. 7D2D shines amongst the rest in my book and those 13 reasons are why.

y 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Speaking as a Linux gamer:Multiplayer is currently a bit buggy (several exploitable glitches and bugs), but that's okay for alpha software. Singleplayer works without issues for me.Overall the game is actually quite fun, especially in Multiplayer (I love PvP). Having to consider other people wanting your stuff (or your life) makes it all the more fun when building your fort and sneaking around in a city or other point of interest to avoid getting seen by players is quite thrilling.If I had to name any, I can think of two downsides:Sometimes, Easy Anti Cheat (a third party tool included to ward off cheaters) is being a pest and causes problems (mostly kicks you from a server). It also didn't solve the cheater problem one bit as far as I can tell. I still see the same amount of cheaters on EAC servers. So you gotta find a server with capable admins that use global banlist and have plenty of staff around to ban cheaters immediately and can restore chunks that have been vandalized by said cheaters.Although not strictly a problem with the game, the developers have an absolutely terrible communication policy. If you're interested in what I mean, you can read up on the whole Linux drama with this game and it will become clear to you what I am getting at. It was bad enough that I felt the need to include it in this review and I still think they should improve this.All things considered, though, I still recommend this game because it's fun.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly enough, this is actually a lot of fun to play and is making faster progress than Rust.It's playable, very much so.Think Rust meets minecraft with zombies.Build bases and scavenge during the day, bolt down the hatches and light the fires during the night.With the stealth/sneak system + the dynamic moving hordes, you feel afraid of the night, not like some kind of super soldier.With a full server filled with voice chat and pvp it feels like a day of "The Walking Dead" gotta make choices with everyone you meet and take their names, you'll need their help when the night comes to protect yourself.Gone are the days of DayZ where ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ rule the world with their "OneManArmy" ♥♥♥♥, everyone is vulnerable.And if you die, thats it, you lose everything and have to start all over again, thats where the thrill of survival comes in.Everyone you meet, you have to make a choice, do you invite them to help you survive and band together?Or do you shoot them like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and watch the global chat fill with words of your disgrace?I've seen forts where people'v came, been called immigrates as they passed through the litteral gates of success and given a home by those who have already started a camp, usually these poor, friendly folks get stabbed to death, and beds destroyed in their sleep by the dishonest fellows they've accepted as "friends."But it's all worth it in the end, you feel like you're in a living breathing world as the zombies flock in great hordes to hunt you down and eat yer brains, if you're playing solo you're obviously doing it wrong, dont be afraid to grab a mic and join the fray online, it's a beautiful thing to experience.Befriend to survive? Or shoot them and take whats theirs.Build, Kill, Survive.Pick 2.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								EDIT Alpha 12.1: Nope, sorry.  Still not enjoying playing this anymore. It is ridiculously dark pretty much all the time. Zombies can be heard almost regardless of distance but, because it is so dark, I can't actually see them until they are almost on top of me. The melee animation looks really stilted now for some reason and even on Adventurer with low spawn settings, zombies are everywhere, all the time. Bears, ditto. Yes, bears are less common since the patch but I still seem to spend half my time running away from either them, or dogs. The Crafting bit of the game has been over run by the Survival Horde part even from Day 1... Maybe I'll come back to it in six months and have another look but, right now, it's on my Can't Be Bothered To Play list.This is really quite disappointing.  I really enjoyed Alpha 11 and clocked up well over 330 hours playing (yes, I know that's not much to many hardcore gamers but it's still my most played EA game on Steam). A12 appears to be rather odd in places and the community discussion boards appear (appear... ) to have a reasonable number of people making legitimate suggestions for improvements and being banned unreasonably quickly. It's definitely very dark, the weather effects are a nice touch but have reduced the visibility substantially and the wet-and-slimey look to the ground is just plain weird.  The bears are an interesting addition but appear far too often in my opinion and the zombie spawn rate appears to have been increased dramatically.I hope the Devs are listening more than some moderators appear (appear...) to be.  This should be an enjoyable game - my last few hours in Alpha12 (Nomad setting) have just been frustrating, dark and stealthing past zombies now seems almost impossible as there's likely to be a dog or bear just around the corner.  The ramping up of the difficulty seems skewed to me.Anyway, I hope those of us who have backed this game in EA (which, after all, is surely the whole point - to obtain player feedback on the game) will be listened to.No, I'm not whining - I'm just looking forward to a patch that resolves a number of the legitimate issues raised by those of us who are supporting the Devs during Alpha in the hope that the final version will be as great as it deserves to be.So, at the moment, I can't recommend this game to new players. I wish it were otherwise as Alpha11 was really good.

number of helpful: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
r 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off I would like to say this is a great game, and hope someday in the future when it is completed this game gets ported to the consoles. There is no game that I know of that has crafting, survival, zombies, multiplayer of this caliber. This game is gorgeous. From the moment the sun sets in game, to the moment the sun rises the game is awesome.When I first tried the game, I was very skeptic, I was like great another zombie shooter game, boy was I wrong. The amount of depth the game has at this early stage is pretty impressive. The Developers are always actively keeping us up-to-date on their progress and constantly showing pics of improvements coming to the game on their blog.I'm currently playing on a public pvp server alpha 9.3. When you first go into the game, it is extremely overwhelming as the learning curve is steep. There is no tutorials so you basically would have to ask people online, or look at some YouTube, wiki, and do some trial and error to learn some of the games mechanics. First person shooter players will feel right at home here, as the controls are basic.When you start your first game, you start out at virtually very little items. You quickly learn that zombies are all around you and you have a limited food supply. You quickly scrounge around in cars, trash bins for food and must collect items to craft basic items to help you with your survival.The crafting menu is straight forward you start out with know recipes such as a stone axe. Crafting an items is simply as just clicking on what you want to craft from the list, drag the components to the grid and click craft. After a short time the item is crafted. As you progress in the game you will find more new books that unlock new recipes. You can create forges that smelt your mining ores such as iron, and you can create a campfire to cook eggs, and raw deer meat (yes you can kill bambi!). Sleeping bags and beds crafted are used to save home locations so when you die you can respawn at them. You can farm food to grow, such as potatoes or coffee beans.The map is huge, plenty of room to roam around and explore or go underground and create secret underground bases by digging. Zombies are slow at day and fast at night, there cute and cuddly but enough to easily overwhelm any player base not properly prepared. You will die a lot in this game, from starvation, diseases and other craziness in the game.So if you’re an explorer or builder type, this game has plenty at its development stage to keep you busy. I recommend playing with friends to enjoy the many "oh ♥♥♥♥" moments you’re going to have trying to survive against hordes of zombies.What also makes this game unique is the importance of certain blocks in the game that form the many structures in the game such as buildings and farm houses. For example cement blocks have both a structural integrity that can withstand a lot of damage and has a threshold on the amount of blocks it can hold when used for building. Exceeding these capacities when building and not placing the proper foundation to support buildings can cause the whole building to collapse, pretty impressive from an engineering perspective. You can fortify buildings and upgrade doors windows etc., to withstand more damage.There are many things planned for the game, such as in game vehicles, npc's, and story etc. This game is a good mixture of everything we love in mine craft, left for dead, and fallout games.It is a great game and I highly recommend!

content:
16, 2014
Early Access Review
								So. 7 Days to Die. This review is based off of the latest build (infinite world gen)This game started off well, a good first alpha build that showed off the features of the game, but lacked content with a limited map and lacking item explations and crafting options.In this latest build, the game now has an infinitely generated world (which I must say is very well done). After an hour exploring i found a mix of biomes from bombed out, desolated cities (including convincing bomb craters, ruined and intact buildings, ect.)  Goergous forests, stark deserts, lakes flush with wildlife, and frozen hilly forests. One could spend hours just looking for all the nifty features the terrain generator can create, and so far, I have found no real broken generator features.The new crafting menu is vastly improved, eliminating a lot of the guesswork required while still requiring a challenge to find and assemble crafting components for rare recipies. Unlike older versions, the recipe shows all materials needed in the grid, but you need to know what the materials are, and find them before you can build the recipe. The UI overhaul adds modular sets for different crafting recipes, eliminating the one huge recipe list, and also adds color-cordinated backlighting to different items, displaying what catagory of item they are. It also fixed the OCD aggravating clipping between the status bars and hotbar (Thank god).The build still has some problems, sound for one is a huge issue. Zombies are unreasonabley loud at crazy distances, making scavenging overly panic inducing, and often causing injury or death because you can't tell how far away an enemy is. Footsteps and impact sounds also feel too roughshod, and could use an overhaul.Overall, I quite love the game, and i'll probably play around with this build a lot more. Until then, good luck surviving everyone :3 (also. Dysentery. 10/10)

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								7 days to die. WOW. Where do I begin? The game offers so many options in such an early stage, it almost feels complete! However, it is not. Since this is an Early Access review, it will be wrote as such.TL;DR at the bottomGameplay7 Days To Die, in my opinion, is a good cross between what DayZ could have been, with Minecrafts building mechanics and crafting, overhauled. From time to time, the controls can be a bit clunky, swaying around in a direction you hadn't intended. Mocap hasn't been integrated yet so walking, running, and other physical motions are dry.  It is however, very polished, and does not interfere with playability. The game itself handles fine on any well equipped PC.UI & VisualsOptions don't boast too many options in terms of video settings just yet, but offer enough to allow you to tune it to run either performance or quality. It isn't recommended to run it in ultra high settings (unless you can handle it of course), but at a mid point to save yourself from the lag in clustered POI's like cities, neighborhoods, and possible player built settlements.The best part visual wise out of the whole thing is that the entire world is smooth. Everything looks natural and polished, and breaks and modifys just like any other voxel game. It is a learning curve to get used to it if you're just coming in from Minecraft, cause the angles of the ground, cliffs, rocks, etc can be offset looking sometimes, but it looks great and plays fine. The worlds themselves keep getting better and better looking with each update. As of Alpha 10.4, this game already looks wonderful. With the right tweaks, its is a place full of wildlife, and the undead.The UI is nice. It has changed a few times in the course of Alpha 7 through 10, but overall is sleek and very efficient, showing you just your essential meters, belt, and compass. The Day and time count are small enough to be out of the way, and still legible. Nothing sticks out in a manner that would block peripherals, so you get full view of whats in front and next to you.MechanicsThe mechanics to the game in general are fantastic. The crafting is what keeps me coming back time and time again. There are literally hundreds of recipes to choose from, and if that's not enough, you can make your own recipes out of items you couldn't normally craft! The community is good at coming up with unique ways to make the not so useful items useful again, and adding the recipes are as easy and copy and paste.There are some glitches and errors that can be frustrating when crafting. At times, the forge will "eat" your materials, so that 534lb of Iron? yeah, it's gone. The same thing happens with the campfire. There have also been times the zombies warp through the walls, and hordes end up inside our fortified prefab house. this doesn't seem to happen with player built bases.Structural integrity is the game changer. There will be no more building massive structures in 15 minutes. You actually have to think about placement. One wrong move, and half, or even all of your building will collapse. It creates ways to make traps, and take down players bases. It's really cool to watch the bricks rain down! It would be nice to see them fall over in a more realistic motion, but that will come in due time.Zombies are pretty terrifying when setup to spawn in large groups. I play the role of a bandit, so my first habit is to try and set up in the wasteland. What might be done quickly in the plains or forest is damn near impossible to do in the wasteland biome. I remember the days of sitting inside the corner of a small 6x8 shack, listening to the hordes whisper and screech in the night as they run by chasing the animals. The fear was real at that point. SoundThe sounds at first can be frightening, which is a good thing. You get that pump of adernaline when hearing the scream of a Spider zombie or a Zombie Cop bubbling up puke. But after a while the sounds become recycled. You might even notice some sounds from other games used. However, Snow zombies will never get old. That sound will haunt you in your sleep.Overall, I rate this game, in its current state, a good 7.5/10. The bugs need to be fixed, cause some of them can cause frustrated players to just quit, and it diminishes the replay value. Pathing is still another thing to consider, but it just tests your FPS skills for the time being :) With my overall hours, I highly recommend this game. With future workshop support, Mods, and a great community follow up, this is one game that is sure to remembered by all Z fans for a long time.TL;DRPros+Good pace of zombie action+dozens of different block styles to design your base with+Lots of loot to find+100's of recipes to craft+Creepy atmosphere (Crying wasteland babies)+Future Workshop and Mod support+Devs are friendly, engaging, and listen to the communityCons-Hackers on mainstream open servers-Random little glitches -Zombies run through prefabs from time to time-unoptimized for low end PC's-Pathfinding on Zombies and Zombie Dogs is poor-Physics are poorOverall: 7.5/10

								So as i update this review as it was orginally stated as a good game let me update it as the game updated :)This game's world is bigger than when i used to play it. It seems not only big but has more stuff in the world. More houses in different areas, some areas are the same but over all it's quite amazing. I love how the developers still update the game. So as an avid survival player... i have to say this game definitely has a lot to offer. Although it's clunky and a bit slow the game has a lot of promise. As i said before you need to get past the graphics and push through the flaws of the game to truly appreciate the game itself. The game has multiple to nearly endless crafting options along with building options. The game has a server base where you can sort of have a private server to play with your friends or you can join an open server with other players. Along with the update- able to add friends, track them on the map, having so many more health conditions... this game truly gives a survival aspect and the developers are definitely supporting the game as much as possible. You can build gorgeous houses and in zombie attacks have them destroyed... be raided by other players.. dig underground for resources, chop down trees, or even reinforce broken town houses. The game has a lot of promise. I do recommend this game... with it's flaws the game itself is quite fun, especially with friends.

content:
er 31, 2013
Early Access Review
								Just because you are unique, does not mean you are useful.7 Days to Die has a problem. It has many problems. Is the Zombie AI awful.....yeah...Are the weapons incredibly stock and unappealing.....Yeah...Is there no risk involved when you can just run back to your house and get your shotgun back after dying.....Yeah...But most of all, 7 Days to Die has one serious problem. It mixes and matches far too many concepts into spots where they do not belong. Base building is slow and unrewarding, when even stone walls can be broken down by the horde, and when breaking the game mechanics is the only way to provide safe shelter. Mining is slow and unrewarding, digging for hours to only come up with coal and nitrite, only to say ♥♥♥♥ it, and use dynamite to blow open caves simply because you can. Combat is slow and unrewarding, when even a huge horde can bring you nothing but some bullets and pieces of paper. Crafting is slow an unrewarding, and in essence, bland, using the usual PICKAXE, AXE, EXPLOSIVE, FENCING objects to build, bringing nothing new or surprising to the table. This game may be an alpha, it may have some quirks, and it may not be perfect yet.But if steam had a return button, I'd be smashing the refund key until Gabe kicked down my door, gripped my wrist ferociously, and lovingly whispered into my ear, "Cut that ♥♥♥♥ out"It's an alpha, and it isn't a fun one, not worth 30 dollars, and certainly not worth a moment of your time.

ry 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Worth to buy and play it now allready; for sure a big YES !!! Of course there need a lot to be done.. and they are working on it.For now: this is a realy great game with a lot more potential for the future! This game is having all a RPG needs: Action, strategie, loots, mining, crafting, building, farming, etc... Start to get building on my self.. building a fortress around a farm-house near water & corn field.  And making a tunnel from the sellar of the house to the grainsilo on the other side of the street. So i can escape or going inside from there to. And set up a lot of wooden spikes to kill the zombies!Everyone can do it the way you like the most.. of course you can build a total new house or fortress everywhere you want on the good balanced map already. The crafting & building system is the most extensive and easy to handle ever seen in games like this!!! Extra hugh thumbs up for this!!! Remember..there are lots of 'zombies' and also wild dogs, giant bees and others to come.. that will try to destroy what you are building... In all the time i played till now (+-50 hrs), i only have 2 little bugs, and no crashes, so that's not so bad for an alpha game i suppose. There is a diversification in the actions from the zombies between day and night.. so better looting, crafting and building in day-time, defending at night is usefull to do. Conclusion: Like i say at the beginning, there is still a lot to do.. but for sure it's already worth to buy and play! For now a lot of hours nice playing-time and we hope it will be more and more in the future.. All by all; Thanks to the makers/developers : nice & good work allready, hope a lot more to come.. To every one; Have lots of fun by playing this exellent RPG xD

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
y 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Game:Survival, horror, zombie and crafting game. Think minecraft but better looking, more intricate crafting and faaaaaar scarier.My Thoughts:When I first had a crack at this game it was brilliant, building my first castle and sniping zombies from the top was rewarding as was the scavenging all the materials required for it and fighting zombies with a stone axe. The game was tough but not overly so. You could got to the easiest setting and learn how it all goes then try harder setting knowing how to build the essentials.Then there was a patch that smashed my hard work. So decided to start again, another patch, hard work smashed. I decided to take a break to preserve my sanity (admittedly a small amount).Well I came back for another bash after a while and things changed for the worse I think.For example, while playing this game now my innner geek would ask (or scream and gibber) the following:Why am I dying when cold? After constructing a shelter, clothes and stood next to a fire.Why am I dying when hot? After removing all my clothes, standing in shade, stood still and drinking water till I'm full.Why am I dying at all in easy mode with no zombies???? Anyway, to the review.Pros:Crafting is quite easy, and gettting materials is fun as everything is destructable. Try going into creative mode and laying tnt around the base of a building then detonating it all with a missile.The graphics are quite nice and the atmospherics are excellent. When the zombies come for you it sends the hairs on the back of your neck right up.The base building aspect is really satisfying, if you manage to live past the first few days.I like the physics too, if you do bother to blast the hell out of that building I mentioned you will see it all fall in sequence, very well done to the devs for that.Cons:Feels too hard mode even in the easiest settings. I know this is a survival game but if you set a game to the easiest mode and STILL die if you are spawned in an extreem biome (snow, desert or the blasted lands) then where's the fun? In previous iterations of this game you could build something glorious, turn on the zombies and see what happens. Now I can barely even survive to build a wooden shack unless I'm in creative. On a side note, there is nothing more demoralising as being told by the game to build a shelter, fire and clothes to stop hypothermia only to die, (very slowly) in your shelter in a lovely plant fibre outfit and cloth armour next to a fire, from hypothermia:(I might try this game again in the future, to see if the devs put something in to turn off the dying every 2 seconds because of being too cold or hot. I would have given a thumbs up before finding out some patches don't allow you to carry on with old saves. However, right now I can't it give a thumbs up.

								Before the A13 update: I loved playing this game, it seemed decently balanced, the wait times to craft or break things didn't seem too slow or too fast.A13 Update: 1st Spawn: I was right next to an irradiated zone so I died seconds after walking into it. 2nd Spawn: Was in a snow biome, I was fully clothed and standing pretty much on top of the fire and I still froze to death. 3rd Spawn: Was in a desert next to wastelands and irradiated zone, almost died of heat stroke a few times, started getting the hang of the new UI (it's terrible) when I came across a resort, I killed the zombles and proceeded to loot the place... it took FOREVER to break into, each door, each baricade takes what seems like years to break, I broke into ONE... yes just ONE room after at least 2 real life minutes of just sitting in one spot staring at the door, I got so bored that I quit right then and there and will not play this game again, at least until a lot of balancing is done.The devs took a fun and what seemed to be (at least ot me) a fairly balanced game and turned it into a grind fest, with lots of just sitting around breaking objects for what seems like an eternity. I used to be addicted to this game but now I can't stand playing it.

Early Access Review
								Feels like the most complete early access game on the market. Has some of the most brutal and gritty atmosphere in any game i have ever played. Crafting is sumblime and has the right amount of difficulty without it becoming repetitative. The zombies are awesome and make the dayz zombies look like a joke. In dayz 15 zombies just teleport through the front door of the building your in and insta kill you. In 7DTD the zombies tear down your house from the foundation!! Huge hordes of zombies destroying your hard build castle peice by peice as you try to defend it with your life. Great building mechanics as well. You can build a huge varioty of houses, a huge skycastle to a normal suborb house. PVP is also brutal and fun at the same time, has an awesome community with many militias to join. Survival is a key part of this game and it is pulled of with flying colors. The newly added level up system is a welcome addition to this epic game!Makes the building in RUST look like some homeless shack city.Makes the Zombies in DAYZ look pitfull in every way (Not as good graphics for zombies in 7DTD but who cares if the DAYZ zombies are this terrible still in 2015 Only thing i would suggest adding is vehicles, to help move around this massive mapUpdate: They actualy added mini bikes soon after i made this review. The better the parts you put into it, the faster and more reilable the mini bike is. It really helps that bad feeling of grinding becuase traveling long distances are no longer a chore. 10/10 100 hours+ and dont plan on stopping soon

								I went up to a glass shower door and broke it with a stone axe because it's fun breaking glass, then I noticed it dropped glass shards. I examined the item and right clicked. And turns out you can eat it. So I ate it by accident and died seconds later from internal bleeding.Today's life lesson of the day: don't eat glass- you'll die.In all seriousness this game is quite fun, especially for being in Alpha. The character creator, the world generator, weapons, crafting, cooking, survival, all that.Especially the character creator - I created numerous alien freakazoid goblin zombie things on it already, including one that looks like Michael Jackson.The survival is also somewhat of a realistic simulation. For instance, it gets you searching for a place to stay during the night and that's quite a challenge itself because the biomes in the game all have different zombie spawn rates (as far as I know at least) and once you settle down you must search the local area for supplies like books to learn recipes, food, water, clothes and other supplies.So, do I like the game? yes.Should you get it? Maaaayyybe, it's great fun with friends, but can be a bit dull if you are playing by yourself, although when you are playing by yourself things such as mentioned at the very start of a review may happen.

content:
er 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm not one to talk poorly of game developers, but I feel this needs to be said so I'll give a fair review of Alpha 13 as I go. - Visually, this latest update did very well. Most everything looks noticeably better.- Alpha 13 essentially made the game copy more aspects of Ark Survival's interface, so if you like that interface, you'll likely enjoy this factor a bit more. - The costs for items is a little crazy now, it seems almost randomly chosen with no real rhyme or reason. Some items are changed to the point they are useless now. Example: for the same amount of materials in Alpha 12 instead of making 25 arrows, you make one. Yes, a single arrow. While this is more realistic, without increasing the power of the arrows to actually make them useful at one arrow per craft... you basically just made them useless as it took multiple arrows in the head to kill zombies at higher difficulties anyway so you'll spend just as much time gathering supplies for arrows in the early game as you would trying to customize your base. All of this is understandable and fine. Here's the big problem... They completely broke the spawns for zombies. Even at low spawns on the second to lowest difficulty on the first night (yes, the first night) you can literally fight an endless amount of zombies if you're spotted even once. A single screamer zombie (Banshee) will call a horde if it spots you. Normally a single horde isn't too bad, but the problem comes with the additional screamers which spawn close to the end of nearly every horde, before it's actually finished. Nearby zombies can alert them to your presence and if they see you, they scream and summon another horde. This is nearly impossible to avoid at all times in the early game as you don't have any feasible way to destroy screamers at a distance or avoid screamers if they happen to catch you in your house at the wrong time.So, if you get spotted once, most of the time it's game over after a long grueling fight which makes you just not want to play anymore. Up until Alpha 13 I would have gladly recommended this game, but until this is fixed I would recommend steering clear of 7 Days to Die.

content:
1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Survival Horror SandboxingStarting the game I found myself in a scene very reminiscent of Silent Hill. A wrecked car sat in the road beside me surrounded by my worldly belongings and the desert wasteland was entirely unfamiliar to me. Gathering up my few worldly possessions I boldly set forth into the unknown and was immediately set upon and ripped apart by a pack of wild dogs.So exactly like Silent Hill then.My next few attempts fared little better. I tried to break into a house and was snuck up on and stunlocked to death by zombies, I approached a car junkyard and mysteriously died with no apparent cause like in the opening of 13 ghosts, and I had another go at meleeing zombies getting myself stunlocked to death.Part of the problem is that zombie moans barely change in loudness depending on distance or facing, so a zombie could be trying to extract itself from someone's scummy backyard swimming pool 3 blocks away and you will still hear it hissing in your ear, which makes it hard to tell when zombies are actually close since you just stop listening eventually.So I quit for a couple of months and came back in another patch when the sound bug had supposedly been fixed. It's still there but not as bad as before, you can't hear them as far and the sound does somewhat scale by distance, just not very well, and I can at least tell the difference between a zombie 20 metres away and one 5 metres awayNonetheless it seemed like a rather dull survival crafting game. Zombies are easily outrun and can be dispatched with little trouble with an easily crafted bow which fires needlessly slowly and draws out the boredom.Maybe I'll go play something else. Oh look it's dark now. Oh I can see another player run... oh no that's a zombie! I'll just nerd tower onto this sawmill roof and wait for morning. Oh god they're ripping down the walls! The roof is falling down!How I survived that first night I'll never know but with that the true survival horror nature of the game became clear to me. As I told my friend of my experience he replied "Just wait til night 7 lol". "Wait, what's this about night 7?", I replied. "You do know why it's called 7 days to die right?"Apparently on the 7th night a massive zombie horde attacks your location. They know where you are and will claw through wood, dirt and even concrete to reach you. If you stand on the roof or take out the stairs they will rip through the walls til the house collapses and brings you to their level. What's more special zombies start to appear including acid spitters, spider zombies, hornets, dogs and things that look like they belong in attack on titan! What's more, the hordes get progressively bigger every 7 days with new specials and more waves.So my next 3 days (as I had reached day 4) were spent in a manic rush to gather supplies and fortify my position. I dug a trench around the house I had taken. I filled it with spikes. I built an extra layer of wall around the first floor with an overhang to keep out spiders. I blocked up the windows and reinforced the doors. I searched for meds, guns, crafting books and crap metals for the defenses. And finally the fated night came around...As the sun set the night was erril quiet. 10pm came, 11pm came, eventually midnight came without any activity. Perhaps my friend was wrong I thought, disappointed and relieved at the same time. Anyway by 6:30am when zombies stop running I was barricaded in my bedroom with 5 zombies clawing at the walls, one of which was crawling in through a gap, with 2 bullets left, 5 arrows and a slither of health!Somehow I managed to survive that and get patched up but it was clear my defenses weren't good enough. And so the cycle continued. 7 days to gather resources and prepare my defenses, 1 night of sheer hell which progressively gets worse each time. I kept thinking I would reach a point where all challenge would end. At one time I had a 4 block deep trench, a 3 block high wall made of metal trussing the second strongest material and one that can be fired through, very high hp, a shotgun, a handgun, hundreds of bullets and a ton of supplies. That was night 42 and saw a ton of acid spitters, I nearly died 3 times that night! I didn't realize they could spit at me through trussing, then they dug under the walls and attacked me from behind, then I retreated into my house and thye somehow made the roof collapse on me by climbing on it!I do think I'm finally at a point where I'm untouchable though, night 70 and 77 saw me emerge without a scratch and my defenses barely scatched but I've now reinforced the sides of the pit with 2 layer thick trussing, and placed another double wall with spikes running under it (so if they break through a bit they continue taking damage and their bodies likely block the hole) before the trench. And I now have a sniper rifle as well. However I was playing on moderate settings and I'm told the last patch dropped the number of zombies to the point where veterans consider the game trivial and even released a patch to restore the zombie numbers!So I think I will wait a few months til more content is added, then try again with max difficulty settings and the community challenge patch for the challenge of my life!In the end I think what distinguishes 7 days from other survival crafters is that it's a true sandbox survival horror. You simply can't waste time on extravagant building projects like in Minecraft, due to building integrity and the very dangerous night hordes you are forced to build for defenses and cannot cheese the game with floating houses. Every minute is precious as you rush for resources or to finish that row of spikes before fun night, and until you become an experienced player you will never feel safe, and even then there are plenty of options for returning the game to the hopeless survival hell we love so much :DSo final verdict is 8/10. The sound bug needs fixing, there needs to be more variety in enemies and the map edge death zone (the junkyard that killed me) needs to be more clearly marked. Can't comment on the multiplayer Reign of Kings put me off that. All in all I'm glad I stuck with it!

content:
3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok i have mixed feelings when it comes to this game.The game it's self is a zombie survival crafting type thing, a bit like minecraft minus the cartoon stuff. When i first got this game it blew away the competition, but really nothing really of value has been added in since then, and i am talking in terms of years/. The crafting got dumbed down and they added in skills that is about it. Oh and minibikes which on any none super server will bug out, lag and more often than not drop your fps to levels you did not think possible, which when looking at games like Hurtworld where they have cars and quadbikes and they run fine makes me wonder why.So when stacked up against other games which are similar in nature like ark which reguarly has massive updates and such, there really isn't a favorable way to compare them.BUT, and big BUT, a sir mixalot type the building is fun, the same way building in minecraft is, you can dig, mine and build structures on the level of sillyness, which is something many other survival games lack, like ark and hurtworld use a type of building system where you have foundations and ceilings and you build bases that all really don't look that different, 7days operates on a block on block system which lets you be far more creative.Now this game is on steam sale atm for 8 quid, and the game is worth that, because sure it isn't the best survival game out there, it is an easy way to throw plenty of hours at something that isn't stressful.Few facts/tips;1). Most the servers are dead atm, however with the steam sale i hope that changes.2). Do you use duel+ GPU's? Well forget about SLI the game runs like a horse with one leg it is waaaay off SLI.3). This game is ment to be played with friends, if you play alone your in for a bad time.4). Avoid pve servers, they already take away from a slightly limited game you will get bored quickly.5). The game rotates on a weekly basis, and at the end of each in game week, a zombie horde will spawn (22:00) and go after a player at random. If you want to avoid this log off before night time.6). The Search function for server sucks, like a lot, be paitent and refresh on a regular basis when looking for a server to play on.7). Build spikes, lots of them, on most servers Zombies run at night and if it is any map other than the standard Navas map, they will lag about like crazy and kill you. Spikes defend your base for you, so you can sit back and ignore them.10). Don't think building below ground will hide your base, opening doors, chests forges etc can be heard from above ground from really far away invest in good blocks.But buy the game, im bored of only like 3 servers having more than ten people on it. I doubt you would have read this far so il say what i want. Buy the game and come suffer with me.

content:
ry 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Picture Minecraft inside an episode of Walking Dead. There is no shortage of zombie games out there, but this indie stands out. At the beginning of the game you basically get dumped into the zombie apocaylpse with next to no supplies. You have to start gathering and building things immediately or you WILL get eaten! Later in the game it has a Last Man on Earth/Omega Man/I Am Legend feel to it as you explore destroyed, zombie infested cities. Build your base well. If the zeds work out where you are (count on it) they will hammer their way through doors, windows, and/or walls.Fair warning; as of right now the game is still in alpha. Every so often the devs bring out updates which require you to wipe your game save and start over. It can be a heartbreaker. Especially since you just found that thing you've been spending the last week looking for! In trade though, the updates are significant and well-worth the trouble of a restart. Last update gave us beer!

								PreView - 


Fan Manual for 7 Days to Die 
A Guide for 7 Days to Die
By: Marbur

			Version Alpha 12: Survival Guide with infos about starting, weapons, tools, zombies, crafting, forging, cooking, farming, buffs, debuffs, base building, server parameter, versions and more.		


This game is an open world with no limits in any direction(east west north south) and everything you see in the world is destructable or constructable. Lets build something together. A house? A castle? A fort? Shoot you can build an entire village or city. Or if you want to be unseen. Build a underground fallout shelter so deep underground that not even the zombies can smell your cooking. But remember, your garden needs sunlight to grow.

Early Access Review
								One of the best "Zombie Survival" games out there, if not the best. However, the main downside is that there is a HUGE learning curve when it comes to crafting, and what you should do to survive. Often times this is more irritating than rewarding as a new player your inventory will be filled with "stuff" you don't know what to do with, and then you will end up dying and losing everything without actually learning anything. So basically... if you are not willing to watch 2hours+ worth of youtube tutorials on how to progress in 7dtd, than I'd suggest passing this one up. It IS fun for a while with friends, but I feel like the crafting system and lack of hints / information is what is truly holding this game back.

Early Access Review
								This game has been on steam/early access for barely over one month and the current newest patch (Alpha build 6) contains more content/fixes/changes than some games that have been on early access for a year+!!!! these guys are serious and are building an amazing game. It does have a rough appearance but there are upgrades to graphics in the works. The core game is just great and these guys claim to be gamers and it shows in their work. so many great ideas and they keep adding to it!  It currently has soooooooo much crafting and content that it beats out pretty much all other games in this genre. the only problem is that it isnt getting the attention it deserves. I urge everyone to checkout this game and make your own decision but in my eyes its a diamond that is being polished continually.key things i want to point out...-FF can be set on or off by server admins. This is great for PVP and Co-oP play!!!-Enemies can be set on or off, again this helps with constructing.-You can host yourself or buy dedicated host.-When you die you only lose items in your quickslot/Belt aka equiped items.-I hosted my own game and was able to change settings next time i loaded up that saved world. So i was able to set FF to off and not worry about players killing me so i could build, then next time i was able to turn it on again. imagine setting server to build mode and then reset and allow people to then attack each others fortified bases. the same goes for enemies, can be turned on or off whenever.-Multiple environments on same map. desert, snow, forest, city all in the same map!-----DIGGING, YES you can dig and build just like in minecraft. construct and deconstruct...Buildings collapse under stress. I was able to digg under a building in key points and cause it to collapse on one side only. made quite a mess too lol- they are planning to upgrade the graphics and overall appearnce so it isnt so blocky. vehicles will be added later around this same time. cant drive a car up a hill made of squares and steps lol. so they plan to make it more smooth/natural while keeping the digging and building system!!
