number of helpful: 20 of 34 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2014
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is one of those games that you want to share with friends who have never played before, and let them experience its' awesomeness with you. It's a voxel based survival crafting tower defense game that touches on gameplay similar to Minecraft and Fallout 3. At first I was quite apprehensive about this game, mostly because of it's poor reviews and, at that time, the price. I nabbed it when it was on sale, then learned that the developers had lowered the price indefinitely. As I played, exploring immense landscapes, learning crafting recipies, and adapting nighttime survival strategies, I began to wonder why this game had gotten such poor reviews. I know now that I should have bought this game long ago, even at its high price. I have enjoyed watching 7 Days to Die's progress more than any other early access game I have played up to this point. I've found myself on more than one occasion reading players' conflicting suggestions and complaints, then come next update realize that the developers had actually listened to that constructive criticism and developed a method to try to satisfy everybody. You can adjust different settings to cater to your specific preferences and difficulty, even after you have started your game. If it gets too easy, just bump up the zombie spawn rate, or vice versa. I wouldn't recommend this one to gamers who have no patience for early access bugs. Don't expect glitch free bliss with this one. But the pros highly outweigh the cons. Judging by what I've seen the game progress to, I have a good feeling that for us patient gamers who appreciate meaningful development...the end product will be well worth it!

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I had been following this game for a little while before it came to steam. I was excited to get my hands on it even if it was only in its alpha stage. When this game first came out it is was a huge disappointment. I was crushed. I couldn't tell you how much I didn't like everything about it. I played about 2 hours trying to understand what was going on and I kept telling myself I was missing something; some huge part of the game that would make it what I thought it was supposed to be. I wasn’t missing anything... The game was so early alpha that it was just a concept held up with a bit of scotch tape and some toothpicks. I deleted the game feeling scammed; like I had just wasted my money. Fast forward a month or so later. A friend of mine had been playing religiously every night. I couldn’t understand what he saw in the game. I was bored enough one night to say what the heck and re download it and jump in for some j-j-j-jolly cooperation. I was blown away! Was this even the same game? Everything had been completely re done. The graphics had been significantly increased. HDR, bloom, lighting. The zombies had rag doll physics (Big plus in my books.). The menu, crafting, UI, features, items, weapons. Everything had been made 100x better and re imagined with more content. The way the game played was amazing compared to the day 1 alpha release which was like scraping your eyes on a chalk board and getting the sound from nails. Everything about the game was, surprisingly better. Like a million times better. Like, how could this happen?! I want to believe in magic but at the same time I also want to believe in god. I went from feeling like a kid at Christmas who was good all year but still got coal to feeling like a man who broke open that coal to find a diamond.This game really was bad when it came out. But since it has gotten the updates that have been promised I can't stop playing. It is extremely fun. It is a mix of FPS, survival horror, crafting, mining and so much more. And! Everything is destructible. If you have looked past this game then give it another glance. I know I am glad I did. It is easily one of my all time favorite games for too many reasons to list. It is the best zombie game on steam. A must own for everyone. This game has come a long way and I am excited to see where it goes.

content:
17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is my updated 2nd review. 9/16/14. My first review was premature and I probably made the game sound much better than it is. If my first review made the game sound like a 9/10, my more realistic 140+ hours of gameplay review would have to put it at more like a 6.5 or 7 out of 10.Overall, I would give this game a thumbs up. The game is fun to play, even with all it's problems. If you really enjoy sandbox type games, then 7DTD will appeal to you, despite all it's flaws. It's like Minecraft on steroids with zombies, ruined cities, sniper rifles, rocket launchers and eventually, will have driveable cars. I'll list a few of what I consider to be the most important points. Keep in mind that at the time of this review we are still in alpha. If you are considering buying the game in alpha, you should expect there to be bugs, a lack of content and other problems. If you get mad at bugs and other problems, don't buy the game in alpha. With that in mind, here is a rough picture of the game in it's current state:Pro: Being tossed into a HUGE game map with zombies and discovering ruined cities and surviving and building your first base = fun, though a bit grindy.Con: The map is huge but repetitive. Running for hours and seeing more of the same randomly generated map biomes gets boring pretty fast. On one hand, the technical achievment of a randomly generated maps is impressive. But then you realize it just gives you a huge bland boring map. There is something very important added to gameplay when you design an intelligent, creative, realistic, immersive, interesting, fun map. Just having an algorithim spitting out huge empty boring maps is NOT an improvement to gaming.You could also view this trend of procedurally generated maps as developer laziness. Gone are the days now when maps where intricately designed to lead the player on a grand adventure of discovery. The trend with the current batch of games is have an algorithim do all the map making. Will we one day have entire games that are procedurally generated and devs don't even need to do anything more than change a few textures and repackage the game with a different title? This will not be an improvement people, trust me.Pro: In MP, it's kind of nice that you can go miles away from all the other players, and build your base, and maybe even find your own city that nobody else knows about (at least for a bit!). So the huge infinite map gives you some privacy, and maybe the ability to have your own private city, at least temporarily.Con: MP servers are having major issues with lag, freeze ups, crashes and rollbacks. One server I was on the server owner couldn't even get it to start up anymore, so he had to delete and start over, thus deleting everyone’s bases and loot. There is speculation that these problems are directly related to the infinite maps as it seems the further out people explore on the maps, the more the server lag increases. It hasn't been definitively confirmed yet, but there is suggestive evidence that it is related to the map size / generation. Now considering we don't need infinite maps, I'd much rather have a stable large map then an infinitely unstable map. I've played many MMOs with huge stable game worlds (and thousands of players), and map space was never an issue. Since this game is not an MMO, and is designed for small sized server populations, we really don't need infinite maps....Please devs, just give us a stable comfortably large map.Pro: Compared to Minecraft, the graphics are amazing!Con: Compared to all games made after 2007, the graphics are not very impressive! With that said, I always give much more weight to gameplay and fun, and graphics are just a bonus. I'd rather play a game with great gameplay and low end graphics any day than a game with top tier graphics and crap game play. With that in mind, the graphics for 7DTD are adequate.Pro: Building bases can be fun!Con: At the moment, the building customization is probably lacking compared to say Minecraft. But that will surely change as game gets updated. Another con for me anyways is the complicated integrity, max load system. If you don't like to do a bunch of math (which I don't, when playing games), it is very likely your uber base that you just spent 20 hours building will ...collapse.Ok, now the absolute biggest con for this game atm, is.....multiplayer. Yes, unfortunately the pain will increase dramatically as you begin playing multiplayer, and you will start to realize just how f**** up this game really is! Multiplayer servers are plagued by hackers in god mode, flying around, spawning them selves all the weapons and TNT they want, filling up peoples bases with bedrock (which can't be removed), shooting through the environment (exploit, not really a hack), causing the server to crash, destroying peoples bases that they spent 200 hours building, etc...the list goes on. I actually have NOT been the target of a hacker ...yet...but every server I have been on has had multiple instances of hackers and other players losing everything because of it.On top of the hacker problem, there are other major problems causing servers to lag and freeze up and crash, and many times this results in a rollback --- causing you lose several hours of progress. For example on my current MP server, I got dropped at one point, and for one hour I tried to log back on, and I couldn't, even though the server was still up. At some point they reset the server, and the next morning when I logged on, everything I had collected the previous night (over a period of a few hours) was gone. One of my game neighbors lost his entire base! I had just happened to get lucky on the previous game session and scored a major haul when I found an unprotected player base / farm, and had looted about 600+ food supplies! After starving for a week (realtime), I had finally hit the jack pot and found 600+ food! Then ….all gone. It makes one feel like it's very pointless to even build up an uber base or gather a bunch of loot, when you know you can log in the next day and it's all gone.Despite all these problems, you can easily play for a hundred hours and not have any of these disasters happen to you. The rollback I just talked about was really one of the few major annoyances I have experienced. Well except when my first MP server decided to quit, and I lost 3 (real life) days worth of gathering and building. But I do constantly hear other players on the servers I am on, complaining about their base disappearing, or large stock piles of loot just vanishing! So it is fairly common.In single player I haven't really had any major problems yet, other than just getting bored of the repetitive nature of the game map and the grind of gathering resources, and building up a first base. And then of course a new update comes out...and you lose your SP game save, and then you have to decide if the new features that were implemented are really worth starting all over again, just so you can see them. My biggest complaint of the SP experience is the game runs a bit laggy. I can run a game like Skyrim on ultra smooth as butter, and here is this game with vastly inferior graphics to Skyrim, yet it runs way crappier. It's not unplayable, but the graphics lag is quite noticable and irritating sometimes. This is certainly because the developers are inexperienced at making modern high end games, it really shows. But despite all the negatives, most of my 140+ hours of game play have been entertaining. But also repetitive and grindy! LoL. A tentative thumbs up. Worth playing if your bored. I can guarentee you will have many hours of fun. But far from being a great game in it's current state. You may just want to keep an eye on this game and wait for another year of development to pass.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pre-A7.0 I would have recommended this game as a decent builder game (with the zombies off, or occasionally turned on) I spent about 30 hours on this game with the zombies turned off most of the time, building, crafting, and eventually testing out various base designs. But beyond that, I have never felt any real desire to survive beyond the hours spent building this or that. This is Minecraft+zombies. Not open sandbox survival-horror.I just spent about 3 hours trying out the new things added with the 7.0+ patch(es) and am finding myself getting frustrated with how the ground has been smoothed, making it difficult to tell exactly where you're striking with an axe or shovel (which makes mining out an underground base almost impossible now, at least with any sense of orginized structure to it). A couple of pluses are the 'veins' of ore now, instead of just a block here and there of this or that ore you can find streaks of ore through the dirt, gravel, and stone layers.The other additions, such as the wait to loot, noise penalties, stealth, and crafting systems are good window dressing for making the game more 'realistic'. But the big selling point for the game (for me at least) has now been ruined, or at the very least complicated for me, the building. As the game stands at this very minute, I can not recommend it at the rather high price of $25. My suggestion: If you're thinking about getting the game, wait until it is out of Alpha to spend your money.PS: I would also like to add that there are better 'sandbox survival-horror' games out there. State of Decay comes to mind immediately. If you want a 'sandbox builder' stick with Minecraft, it's less expensive and for now, better over all. If the developers don't flub things up too badly, in a years time 7 Days to Die could be one of the best sandbox survival-horror games out there. -IF- they don't flub it up...

content:
ry 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have about ten hours right now on this game and I have to say I don't get the haters.  This game is far superior at its current stage of development than most others.  I love the fact that you can change the zombies to the classic George Romero slow walking zombies or even turn them off if you want.  The crafting system is pretty good and fairly easy.  I would only recommend a tutorial on using it.  The addition of more biomes is deffenately a plus now just adding in some weather for rain and snow and your all set.  I have read some bad reviews about this game and I can tell you from my experience with this game, those reviews just don't hold any truth.  They might have had some validity in the begining but those issues have apparently been delt with.  All in all I'm glad I bought this game and would recommend it to any one considering buying it.  If they keep working on it and, I'm sure they will, It will deffinately be worth the price.  As of the writing of this review the game currently has 3 different game modes, single player and multiplayer, adjustable modes for the zombies, many differnt blocks for building and sculpting the environment, a vast crafting system, four different playable characters, and just plain tons of fun.  If you ever wanted a game that combines Minecraft with State of Decay with Tower defense and a whole plethera of other games but done in a more grown up style, this is deffinatele the game for you.

28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'd give this game a 3/5. I played this game alot before it went on to steam.  It was Alpha 1 and they were going in such a unique direction where the zombies were a legitimate threat at night and nowhere was safe, so you had to board up your house and hope they dont knock your house down into rubble, however, the very next update removed all of that and went in a fairly standard, well worn, direction of making a completely safe house where the zombies sit idly outside.  It's like minecraft where they sort of sit outside, hopeing for you to open the door.  Once outside, the game turns into a call of duty nazi zombies gun fight minus the difficulty.  It's like playing round three throughout the entire game.  You could always jack up the difficulty, but i'd rather not have poor AI zombies take 2 shots to take me down.  I'd assume the online gameplay may be better and there are promises of a semi return to their original idea in Alpha 1. but even their promises only offer a semi-return to it "if you make amature mistakes" which doesnt provide quite the same thrill the original Alpha 1 release did for me.  I'd do my research on whether or not the multiplayer is worth it to you, because the core ideas as of alpha 6 are not worth the 35$ i paid.

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is a highly customizable zombie survival crafting game set in an apocolyptic world. It is still in alpha, so take this review with a grain of salt.1) Graphics - (8/10) Stunning. With the settings maxed out, this game is on par with many AAA games of today. The settings can be played with to suit your PC, and there is a fair chance your PC will run this game. It caters to both spectrums of graphical quality, largely settling in the medium-high range. (It runs at approx. 20-30 fps on a laptop with Intel HD 5500 graphics, or 60 fps maxed with a gtx 1060). The lighting is among the best I have ever seen in gaming. 2am inside your small base, completely pitch black, you figure out how to craft a torch (you also start with one if you still have it) then the area illuminates in a way realistically resembling a torch. Two things that could use tweaking - "Torch Lag" where on particularly slow PC's using torches to light your base will half (or worse) your framerate. And the instant change of terrain upon going from rain to snow or vise versa (more noticable in snow biomes) make that change more gradual.2) Sounds - (9/10) You will be on the edge of your chair when you hear zombies shuffling through the grass just outside your mediocre base you hastely constructed 2 hours before nightfall. Your finger will also be hovering over the pause button when you hear the terrifying screech from one of the "things" scrambling around just outside your abode. You sit there silently, not daring to light a torch, or cook the meat that you foolishly left in your inventory. The screech soon converts itself into a bang as the monsters catch onto the scent of the raw meat. They are at your door. You wonder how long the scrap metal laden boards of the door will hold against the ravaging beasts as one layer of material breaks away, Bringing you one step closer to death. Your attempts to repair the continuous damage are futile, as you are now flanked on both sides. The zombies are now breaking down your walls, and your are completely helpless. The hinges on your door give way, and you are swarmed as if the zombies were angered bees. That is the end of your story. A story named 1 Day to Die. Usually this only happens maybe once. Some sounds, however are too loud, even if they are going for realism.3) Gameplay - (8.5/10) - The menus are easily navigatable, so all of your seemingly trivial supplies are easily accessed. In addition to your inventory, you have easy access to your character panel (you can create and customize your own character in MANY different ways. Don't like your nose? Feel free to give yourself a nosejob!). You can craft armor that provides various protection against diffent types of damage, be it a zombie smacking you across the face, or the warm unforgiving sun of the desert. There are many different biomes, and you better hope you came equip with weather appropriate clothing or your goose may be cooked. Or frozen depending on where you are at. Be wary of stepping into a lake as the wetness will amplifify your loss of body heat. There is armor ranging from plant fiber to a suit of iron, that even zombies would have difficulty penetrating. Speaking of iron, you can mine that in caves or your own manmade mine. The mines differ GREATLY from the likes of Minecraft, and they are infinitely more realistic looking. You could build your manmade mine inside your base. Base building is definitely one of the most innovative features of this game. You place frames, and can use materials you've collected to upgrade the durablity of those blocks. Each upgrade has different models, and you are likely to feel more safe behind a wall of scrap metal reinforced wood walls, or even concrete or rubar walls. But always keep in mind... You are NEVER completely safe in 7 Days to Die. You will always have to leave your base to search for food and water, and your own bases defenses may just be your demise. If you manage to be successful in your adventures, you will level up, and earn skill points to spend that will make your continued survival just a little bit easier. If you don't go wandering in the wee hours of the night without heavy artillery... Even WITH heavy artillery, you might just find yourself on the correct side of the wellness bar.4) Animations (8/10) - This is the section, that the developer could touch up a bit. The deer running animation is still rather silly, even after many ALPHA updates, but the zombies animations (Especially running) exceed expections. There is even an death animation that you get to see the zombies feasting on your body! Cutting down trees also has a neat (TIMBER!) animation, which is far better than the previous "collapse" animation. OVERALL - (8.5-10) - This awesome game is still in alpha, even though it feels past needing that label, as this game is more than complete. There is TONS of content to enjoy and to be terrified about.  If you are in the market for a survival game, even if you believe zombies are cliche, give this game a try. Be a walking cheeseburger for a hungry zombie today!

								It is kinda like Fallout it may not be pretty but it gets the job done.They are making improvements and updates on a regular basis,and stay in touch with the community.This is Alpha but so far i like where most of it is going and how things are being handled.The random maps are a welcome and there is plenty of loot to be had but use it wisely.It is first person view and the zombies are varied and for the most part not to over whelming if your careful and quiet,They do walk slower at daylight so you will want to do most your scavenging during the day.They can charge at night and do gather in hordes with specials and other infected so stealth is the most important.They can also dig and climb to get at you and they can tear down your building to get at you unlike most others games where your home is safe here it is always at risk.You can also set traps like spike strips,dig holes with spike strips which is my favorite way to watch them die.You will have to repair or replace damage done to your buildings or traps so make sure to keep up on that so they do not get to you.You can dig under ground and build just about anything you can think of underground which keeps you safe from zombies but makes getting supplies a little more work and takes longer to build.There also are dogs which can be a big threat early on if not prepared for them,so when you first start your best to try and craft a decent weapon and find a building the first night.I think for now i have said enough i will post the Pros and Cons now Pros Grow Crops for foodNice crafting and buildingDecent Zombies Lots of things to lootHuge mapsConsNeeds more crafting like candles and oil lanternsCould use a map to mark locations or points of interest like water or good looting areas,towns ect. Note: it does have a map just no way to mark things it just shows where you been when you walkTrapped doors to hide your entrances better and maybe make traps for zombiesBetter starting gear at least give basic first aid and some kind of weaponNeeds a real offline mode for single player so you can still play if you have no internet. If you wish to play alone as of now you need to be logged into steam before it will launch the game and let you play.Suicide option to be put back in for single player as it stands now if you fall through something or get stuck the only way to get out is to either wait to starve/die of thirst or reload the game to reset yourself.Finally Alpha 10 is coming with a lot of changes and as the games changes i may change my review and update it.In short if you like building,crafting,zombies,co-op this is a good game to get and out of the survivalist games this is one of the better ones in my opinion and worth the purchase .8/10

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								7DTD is a Single/Multiplayer Zombie Survival game that even if it's still in its Alpha phase, allready worth Buying.When I first Bought this game it was in Alpha 4 or so, and looked a lot like Minecraft.That, to be honest was one of the Reasons why I Bought it in the First place, but i stayed because it is one of the most Fun Zombie Games plus it is a Game with the "Build-your-own-Base-and-defend-it" aspect that is really Enjoyable to Play.The Fun only really begins when you Start playing Online with one or more Friends, because the Building and Fighting off Zombies gets more Fun (and Hilarious) when done with Friends even though the Singleplayer is Fun too.About the Gameplay, Graphics and what not:The Controls are Simple, nothing too fancy that you would Loose yourself in.Movement is smoothly, but looses Precision when your FPS are fairly Low.The Textures are Surprisingly High-Res, the Water shader is really good too.When I first Jumped into the Game and checked out what it was about, I was Surprised at how the Game looks Graphic-wise.Soundwise this Game is pure Genius too, the Zombies sound Scary (even though they're not, more about that later), the sounds of everything else is Okay too.The Reason I'm only saying Good things about this Game is because  they Paid me for it and told me they'd Kill my Family if I say something bad it is still in early Alpha, which suggests that you shouldn't be so Harsh on it, and also the Game is simply Amazing as said before!The Game is getting Frequent updates, and the Communication between Developers and Community is Very open.But if anyone wants some Critisism on this Game:Right now as it is, the A.I Pathing is quite Glitchy and seeing Zombies Poledancing on a Lantern post isn't something Rare.What i really do not Enjoy one bit is that there is a Timer for opening Cars and other Loot Containers such as Crates, Duffle Bags and Desks.The Timer IS a good idea, but it just takes so long to open Containers. (about 1 Minute if i'm correct)You can deactivate that setting when Joining a World though, so that is not that Big of an issue.If the Developers would change the Time it takes to Open a Container I would propably even use that Feature, since it Stops you from Rushing through a City, opening all the Things to never be seen again.This is a good Transition to coming over to the Next Downside:Its really Easy to just Run through a whole City in less than 10 Minutes or so since the Zombies are rarely an Issue and finding Weapons is way too easy, but the Night takes this Back down because its rather Difficult to Survive if you haven't build a good Base.I am looking forward to the Full Release of this Game, and Proud to say that I Supported it since almost from the Start.I'd Recommend this to everyone that likes Zombie games with a nice Atmosphere, and Enjoys Fighting off said Zombies in a Self-Made Base.I think even Minecraftians will Enjoy this Game.TL;DR: Its a Zombie Tower Defense game with Crafting elements.Buy it.This was my First Real Review of a Game on Steam, let me know if I did good.

content:
2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alone, in an abandoned gun store, I barricaded myself into a dark corner in the hopes that I would not be sensed by the creatures that lurked about outside. I had been struck earlier, and was suffering the early stages of the infection. I hadn't eaten in days, and all I had were some eggs that I had found in a birds nest this morning. Expecting the cold grip of death at any moment, as I hear the deathly screams of the undead outside, and my body beginning to eat itself, I quietly slip a raw egg into my hand from my backpack. I lay hunkered down, crying silently, as I eat the raw egg to stop the hunger pains, knowing full well it was a gamble; that the raw eggs would most likely cause me some sort of illness. Although I knew the risks, I wasn't prepared for the sh*t stormof blood that erupted from my ♥♥♥♥. I began losing consciousness, but remained alive by popping painkillers. Finally, daybreak came about, and as I emerged from my hiding place, I lost the battle with my bloody diarrhea, and slipped into a coma. This has been the 8th time that I have come so close to death, only to be rescued by some mysterious stranger. I awoke on my bed fully refreshed, no longer starving, thirsty, or infected. Thank you mysterious protector. You are the batman of the apocalypse.

content:
er 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Seven Days to Die...seven? Really? I've been trying so many times! I even tried to play without zobies....and guess what...I died anyway! And thats wonderful!...This game is really fun to play, it has a true post-apocalyptic atmospere you can feel on your every single step. The slightest unusual sound during your scavenge for any useful piece of scrap causing you nerve-wrecking anxiety. The perception of rapidly shortening daylight goes hand to hand with desperate need for shelter and at least an illusion of safety..."Can I get back to my provisional base in that wooden cabin I found yesterday or shall i prefer to scavenge a little bit longer in this ruined tenement on the city outskirts...maybe I will finally find some ammo to my half-broken hunting rifle, maybe some can of dog food....I am so SO hungry! Ok, lets search few more rooms and stay overnight. This bulding is pretty tall. I bet they wont find me on the roof..."And then the nigh comes."...That was really BAD idea..."CONS:- It's an aplha game, there is a lot of mistakes and glitches....and imagine that, it is not even finished yet! (sarcasm tag)PROS:- Well-made survival simulator- Zombie-apocalypse atmosphere- Random open world generator- Crafting and building system- ONE OF VERY FEW EARLY ACCESS GAMES, WHICH IS CONSTANTLY UNDER DEVELOPMENT AND YOU CAN ACTUALY SEE THE PROGRESS ALMOST EVERY COUPLE OF DAYS!!!Yeah I like it - 8/10 - (with a potential to get much more better when it's finished)

content:
er 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review for version A13I had to change my recommendation since the game became a major overhaul and goes now in such a bad direction that I don't enjoy to play it anymore. You can find my first review further down.In short, 7d2d stole a lot of ideas from games like ARK or Rust and implemented it. Also implemented it pretty bad. I'm not even talking about the tons of bugs, they will get fixed eventually.Not sure what exactly happened, but I would say that someone else now has the creative lead. One of the strong sides of the game was so far the easy gameplay with a lot of depth.This clearly is getting completly changed and complex systems replace the easy one. Systems that add not so much depth, but mechanics that constantly force you to do things. It also prevents you from easy starting anew again. Instead of making the endgame more interesting/rewarding they made the beginning painful (not in terms of difficulty, but in terms of achieving anything). IT's A GRINDING GAME NOW!!!!A few examples:> Characters got gimped and a skill system was implemented that adds nothing except to bring your char back to where he once was without the skill system.> There is now poop in toilets> There is now a heat system in place that forces you to change your clothing constantly> There is just one sort of meat in the game instead of a different one from every animal, in general there are less recipes available> The hud got simplified which took a ton of immersion away (you need now to go trough different menus to see for example how hungry or thirsty you are> Fighting mechanics took a blow for the worse. Graphics will prevent you from making clear shots, also the way zombies move now make every shot unpredictable> You can literally be safe now with just tons of wood spikes around you, building anything more is not fun now but just a pain in the ♥♥♥ that needs tons of ressources to keep it repaired (repairs were free before)> Less interaction with objects, less materials, less recipes, takes a lot of immersion away> Random terrain generator is completely ♥♥♥♥ed up now - you basically need to build in the desert, because you won't find anywhere else water. And water will now disappear in time.I could go on for hours like that. The games has issues that would need attention (implement NPCs, make a better random generator, more prefabs, better security against hacks, implement electricity or similar system with logic operators, etc...) but the devs ignore those completly and invest instead only time into changing systems that were fine. As it stands I can only recommend the game to play the older A12 version. That one is a lot of fun. Other than that I'd recommend to buy something else.------------------------------------------------Review for up to version A12Yes, I recommend it. It's an awesome game and you would miss out a lot by not playing it if you like zombies and/or base building, crafting, survival games.Grab one or a few good friends, open a server and try to survive against waves and waves of zombies during the night while you scavenge for food, supplies and weapons during the day and fortify your base as good as you can.Always in a race against the clock. The game get's harder the longer you play it. Building on a spot generates heat and this attracts zombies. Also every night until the final 7th night the zombies get harder.If you survived a week and manage to rebuild the damage you got on the 7th night it cools down. But make no mistake, because week 2 will be harder than week 1.Only when you managed to survive around 7 or 8 weeks you will be pretty safe. That's also the time to quit and play on harder difficulty as there is not much else to do after.Multiplayer Servers work different and would in theory give a longer incentive to play, but be aware, that the not whitelisted multiplayer servers are completly flooded with hackers.The game uses the unity engine (big mistake for any serious multiplayer game nowadays) and you will loose all your stuff and well built base because they take it over with hacks. So multiplayer is a complete NO-GO! with this game.Be VERY AWARE of that before buying it.

content:
er 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game on sale for 10€ since it's PvE style offers a different take on the well saturated open world survival genre. The review is based on Alpha 15.Pros:+PvE approach offers the comfort of playing on a sandbox server at day and handing you big scale fights at night (especially on the 7th night a week).+Landscaping/Mining. This is something that a lot of the other survival games are missing.+Characterleveling and skillsystem.+Randomly generated maps and a static map.+Quests.Cons:-Bad optimization. I get 40fps and below (GTX970/FX8370/16gb@1080p) next to big buildings and hordes of zombies which doesn't change when lowering graphics settings.-Graphics can't compete with other games of the genre.-Controls aren't fully customizable.-Very few special infected.-Somewhat clunky and unfinished UI.-No PvP due to small servers and the way the game works.-Bad and easy to abuse AI.-You will reach the point of "What now? Why am I doing this?" fairly early in this game if you aren't into straight up sandboxing.Conclusion:While playing this game I couldn't stop thinking about how Rust does everything (apart from the Zombies obviously) better - whether it's looks, optimization, controls, interface or the actual gameplay. It's not DayZ-bad but there's still a whole lot to be done for a game that has already spent more than 3 years in Early Access.The real buzzkill to me is what is supposed to make this game different: PvE base defending. Having 50 generic zombies literally pile up on your doorstep and slaughtering them 1 by 1 through holes in the walls just isn't my understanding of a fun and well thought out game concept. Also there are obstacles zombies can't get accross and if you feel like you won't be able to hold your base you can just hop out and kite them all away until the night is over since zombies won't attack empty bases if there are players around.I recommend to not buy this game at this stage although this stage could mean never as many other EA survival games have shown.

content:
ry 12, 2014
Early Access Review
7 Days to Die is an Open-World Sandbox Zombie Survival Crafting Game set in a voxel-based world. You are thrown into the world with nothing but the clothes on your back and from there on it's up to you to survive. Looting, building and exploring during the day and most likely hiding in the basement biting on your fingernails hoping to survive during the night."If Minecraft and DayZ had a baby,  7 Days to Die would be it."I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game, and will continue to put hours into it. Remembering the game is in Alpha is exciting as there is plenty of more new content to be added. I love the freedom in building and exploration, as well as the difficulty and rush to get stuff done before the night settles in. If you are a fan of DayZ or RUST, 7 Days to Die is something you cannot miss.7 Days to Die : 82/100

content:
ry 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I whole-heartedly recommend this game. If you have been sitting on the fence wondering whether this is just like all the other sandbox survival games out there just stop it and purchase this game right now.This game plays great solo, co-op, or pvp depending on your tastes.This game delivers a real challenge and you will die a lot at first until you become familiar with what you must do to survive. There is no tutorial but there are lots of videos on youtube and helpful people on the forums to answer questions.Crafting, building, exploring, survival.....all are done exceptionally well especially for a game at this stage of development.I have owned this game for 1.5 years as of this writing and can attest that the developers are active and passionate about this game. There is very little risk of abandonment that I can see and even if it were to happen the current game is worth the price all by itself so you just can't lose.There are a lot of exploration and survival sandboxes out there but this one stands apart due to its voxel based world and the sheer fun of playing.Now the negative.... Like all of the sandbox survival games in early access there comes a point where all the threats have been overcome and then the game is boring. The good news is that tougher enemies are planned for this stage of the game and quests and NPCs that you can gather as followers will extend gameplay beyond the initial survival scope. But that isn't in yet.Also like all early access games you must be patient and forgiving as bugs and wipes will cause you  pain. But if you enjoy experiencing games as they develop and are interested in the survival sandbox genre you will absolutely love this game.

content:
y 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is not necessarily unique in what it offers : Survival, Zombies, Guns and playing with others, but it combines elements from games like Minecraft, too. You need to allocate resources in order to make things yourself, or trade for better items. Need iron armor? Have fun acquiring it. You'll need not only someone friendly to trade it from, or you can hunt for the schematics, items for a forge and recipes, then gather the materials and do it yourself ( my preferred method, I'm only a bit anti-social ).  So, about the 'Like' or 'Similar To' Minecraft bit : I've never played the game, or seen its cubey appeal, but that doesn't matter too much to me. The main pull from it seems to be the open world mining and building system, and I think its quite fun. In 7 Days to Die, you actually need to think about things like load bearing mechanics, and structural integrity.. though that doesn't mean you can't build some very impressive structures.  Another nice thing? The Developers update the game with either larger patches, or hotfixes rather frequently. So, if you find a problem or issue regardless of what hardware combo your PC features, there's probably someone else that has either the same or similar issue, and the Dev's know.  So, here's the end of a review, one of many for the game. Yes, it's an alpha, and it might have the occasional glitch or FPS drop. Thing is far as I'm aware, it's what an Alpha is for : Adding items and fixing bugs, at least a friend tells me so. I believe him. Been playing this myself in single player, or on servers with or amongst others since late Alpha 8 or so, it comes reccomended from me.. -if- you like these sorts of game elements, listed above. Sure I missed something.

content:
ber 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been playing and following this game since kickstart and it has been an interesting ride. There have been times the updates didn't do what we wanted or, more often enough broke the gameplay. But we have to remember that this is an EARLY ACCESS game currently and it is still in Alpha. The developers are usually quick to fix the game breakers and are making regular progress towards their listed goals. As a singleplayer game, it is fun for a while and definitely worth sinking some hours into. As a multiplayer game, it is fantastic. There are many different interactions in MP with some people being friendly and willing to trade items and there are some who would rather take by force. I was dissapointed most in the map. In a multiplayer environment it was easy to just run around and find people, but now with random world generation, it has become an entirely new game. Perhaps the best feature of this game are the consequences. Every little thing you do has an effect. Drinking unboiled water might fix your thirst for a time, but you stand a good chance of contracting a disease. Eating certain food types boosts energy but drains hydration. Choice of builing location is critical. If you build next to a road or city, someone may find you. Too far away from loot spawns and you're going to tooless. TL:DRThis game is great and offers a lot of features and performance especially in alpha/early access. It can be buggy and there are things that need to be tweaked/fixed but it is worth it to play nonetheless. I highly recommend the game and suggest you pick up a copy to support the developers as they improve this game.

content:
ry 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								One of the few zombie survival games that has an emphasis on the survival part. By this I mean the scavenging for supplies,  building up defenses, learning to hate zomdogs, and other things to last the night, especially the 7th day horde. As opposed to just run and gunning to a safe room or simply devolving into a deathmatch once someone finds a gun.My primary complaint (as of writing this) besides the expected bugs and a need for a bit of optimization. Is the underground/mining part could use a bit of work. While they (the devs) have done things to not make it quite a necessity, it is useful but still tedious, boring, and mostly safe (no underground enemies and zombies don't really dig).Overall 8/10

content:
ber 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been playing and following this game since kickstart and it has been an interesting ride. There have been times the updates didn't do what we wanted or, more often enough broke the gameplay. But we have to remember that this is an EARLY ACCESS game currently and it is still in Alpha. The developers are usually quick to fix the game breakers and are making regular progress towards their listed goals. As a singleplayer game, it is fun for a while and definitely worth sinking some hours into. As a multiplayer game, it is fantastic. There are many different interactions in MP with some people being friendly and willing to trade items and there are some who would rather take by force. I was dissapointed most in the map. In a multiplayer environment it was easy to just run around and find people, but now with random world generation, it has become an entirely new game. Perhaps the best feature of this game are the consequences. Every little thing you do has an effect. Drinking unboiled water might fix your thirst for a time, but you stand a good chance of contracting a disease. Eating certain food types boosts energy but drains hydration. Choice of builing location is critical. If you build next to a road or city, someone may find you. Too far away from loot spawns and you're going to tooless. TL:DRThis game is great and offers a lot of features and performance especially in alpha/early access. It can be buggy and there are things that need to be tweaked/fixed but it is worth it to play nonetheless. I highly recommend the game and suggest you pick up a copy to support the developers as they improve this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is not necessarily unique in what it offers : Survival, Zombies, Guns and playing with others, but it combines elements from games like Minecraft, too. You need to allocate resources in order to make things yourself, or trade for better items. Need iron armor? Have fun acquiring it. You'll need not only someone friendly to trade it from, or you can hunt for the schematics, items for a forge and recipes, then gather the materials and do it yourself ( my preferred method, I'm only a bit anti-social ).  So, about the 'Like' or 'Similar To' Minecraft bit : I've never played the game, or seen its cubey appeal, but that doesn't matter too much to me. The main pull from it seems to be the open world mining and building system, and I think its quite fun. In 7 Days to Die, you actually need to think about things like load bearing mechanics, and structural integrity.. though that doesn't mean you can't build some very impressive structures.  Another nice thing? The Developers update the game with either larger patches, or hotfixes rather frequently. So, if you find a problem or issue regardless of what hardware combo your PC features, there's probably someone else that has either the same or similar issue, and the Dev's know.  So, here's the end of a review, one of many for the game. Yes, it's an alpha, and it might have the occasional glitch or FPS drop. Thing is far as I'm aware, it's what an Alpha is for : Adding items and fixing bugs, at least a friend tells me so. I believe him. Been playing this myself in single player, or on servers with or amongst others since late Alpha 8 or so, it comes reccomended from me.. -if- you like these sorts of game elements, listed above. Sure I missed something.

content:

Early Access Review
								7 Days to Die is the best survival crafting game I have played.  It's crafting is similar to minecraft, yet physics/structural integrity matters.  The survival aspect is actually challenging and fun.  The game is routinely updated and improved upon.  Having played the game in several different builds, it's had many great changes/improvements throughout it's development.  For being in early access it's surprisingly well polished.  Not a ton of bugs, and very playable at this time.  In my opinion this is the best survival crafting open world game available if you like PvE.  I honestly haven't even tried PvP, I have a few friends who also have the game and it's a blast building a base, surviving hordes and then venturing into cities to make another base and try holding off the zombies as long as possible.

content:
ry 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Unlike a good bit of the other people writing the reviews that I've seen, I actually have time playing this game (ie. more than 15 hours). Any respectable gamer knows that isn't even a chop-shop games amount of time to beat. With said time, I've been building the "best fort ever", mining, crafting, getting a handle on the zombie horde times and how to survive them, and playing each and every game mode. All have a great way of balancing the fixes of the other mode. For example, survivor leaves you with a map that will eventually be looted out of all objects left around for you without going into folder files and changing things. When you switch to the zombie horde mode, you get care packages filled with a bunch of random weapons, tools, accessories to survive the upcoming battle. The only problem I've seen so far are the glitches like in zombie horde where the zombies just stop appearing. This could likely be due to not overtaking my strong fort on the first wave and giving up. When you finally feel burnt out of the crafting, scavenging, etc, you do have the "cheat mode" option for your survival game where you can place just about (if not) everything in the game. This fixes your loot problem as you can simply go into cheat mode, fill up bags with these items while on a password basis, and then switch it back to public playing and no cheats. It's great for the server host to keep things fresh, fair, or even down-right crazy. I highly recommend you buy this game if youre a fan of the sandbox/crafter games. It's a huge step up from other said games with a zombie mode- counting graphics, AI, and everything else in the mix.

number of helpful: 18 of 31 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I remember when I first started playing this game, the first hour of frustration trying to figure it out before it finally clicked and it was suddenly so much fun. It was literally my favorite game, I remember calling my cousin just to tell him he needs to buy it so we could play together. He doesn't even play games, I was just so excited I wanted someone to ♥♥♥♥ around with on this crazy new game I found, it was so fun.That was back in A9 or so, though, and I hate to say it's gone downhill from there. While the game improves visually (it's honestly damn sexy for a voxel game especially if you get to play it on max) the fun just slowly disappears. I'm not getting bored of it, it's just getting not fun. Crafting is being dumbed down while survival is getting harder, the interface has been so simplified that it's become complicated (it makes sense if you've played it) and the scavenging/foraging has turned into literally nothing more than "hold click until the tree/rock/dirt's healthbar reaches nil" which takes absolutely forever on everything now and just makes it feel even more repetitive than it already was.I've tried a few times to play it during A13 and now it's finally reached the point where I just can't. I'll try again in A14 but for the time being I can't even reach the point where I can craft a forge (literally the point where the game actually starts) without giving up out of boredom. It's just grinding now, except instead of killing zombies you're killing foliage. It's much less suspenseful.If they can stop trying to complexify and simplify at the same time I think the game's still got a chance, but right now the game's developers seem more confused than I do and that's never a good sign.

								Even though this game is just in alpha, it's quite amazing and the sheer amount of content for an alpha is through the roof. It doesn't require an expensive computer and runs very smoothly. The progression is very good, you can basically go from being an outsider in an apocalypse to the king of the world in this game. Difficulty is highly customizable, which means every player can tailor their game to theri own liking, including how long a day lasts, or how much of that will be night. I'm definitely recommending this game, it's by far the best zombie survival game on the market today. Can't wait to see what it'll turn into.

content:

Early Access Review
								The game is currently in an alpha version and is neither complete nor error free, but has a lot of gameplay and fun. You can play solo on your pc or online on servers (many fans are providing servers).It will take some time to learn to survive the start.7 Days to Die is a survival game and a combination of a FPS zombie shooter with minecraft. In the starting phase you try to survive while you are collecting the materials for crafting your first equipment.Then you are busy with the following things:Exploring the map to collect materials and recipes and improving the equipmentKilling zombiesBuilding a defense base to survive the nights with ever-increasing waves of attacking zombiesRepairing and extending the baseThis game is even in early access better than many "fully developed" games.In my guide you can find more Infos:


YouTube™ Video: Ep 23 Day 21 Horde Night 7 Days To Die Alpha 15 

			Views: 233		

			Hello fellow zombie hunters! Let me know what you would like to see in up coming videos in the comment section below. Please Like Share and Subscribe!

content:
2014
Early Access Review
								The Survival Horde Crafting Game!So… if you have tried a game like Minecraft - you will understand some of the gameplay here. Just add a few things to your vision of Minecraft: 1. Remember the paranoia from Left4Dead when you encountered the witch first time? That feeling will be there much                 more… almost all the time… Especially at night!2. Add the lack of Gravity from Minecraft into this game and add some better looking graphics.3. Add zombies… a lot of zombies… daylight is as in the movie “Night of the Living Dead” and the nights are more like “World War Z”4. Add a lot of guns! To boil it all down it’s a mixture of the best from Minecraft added with the best from games like Left4Dead or Rust or DayZ.If you’re into paranoia, zombies and survival games – then this is it!Haven’t tried a game that after 30 minutes play forced me to crawl into a corner with my torch inside a small church for another 30 minutes of play time… just staring at the entrance and waiting for daylight to come!

ber 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								This review also includes having played the A15 Experimental.Temperature system is still incredibly broken despite being added at the start of the year, you overheat for no reason, for example i was overheating in a hills biome while my character was wearing zero clothing because i was trying to cut down a tree, you still overheat in snow biomes and you still overheat in deserts at night.Spawning is still horrible, enemies still spawn behind you a meter away and your first clue that one has spawned so close is when they hit you.Minibike is still incredibly broken, disappears, falls through the world, very choppy and glitchy to use.Trader system added, which sounds great, until you find out that they are not a 100% spawn at the rare trader POI's, came across 7 trader POI's with zero traders.Resource gathering is still super grindy, takes forever to get resources so even a small shack can take hours of farming to upgrade.The already rare ore deposits have now been nerfed even more, yet to find a single deposit anywhere, if i wanted to mine for 7 hours in a row i would play minecraft or a spelunking game.Wellness system still sucks, even eating the best food and drinking the best drinks takes forever to raise it by a few, which taken into account by zombie spawning behind you and if you die you lose 10 is a horrible system.The A15 update adds almost no content compared to A14, there is a few new additions but they are minor and while i note there is a lot of rebalancing and bug fixing, there is no content or substance to hold you if you have already played a lot in A14.

content:
r 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Best game I have played in a very long time.  It is still in developement, but is better then anything most major game studios have put out in years.  Easily.  - If you at all have interest in killing zombies then this is for you.  - If you at all enjoy immerisive survival(ie splinting your leg when you take a fall, drinking boiled water instead of water straight from a pond) this is for you. - If you like exploration this game is VERY MUCH for you.  - If you like crafting/building games (ie minecraft) this game is right up your alley. -Please note, this game will take you more then a half hour to understand.  It is hard, you will die, a lot.  Once you get your feet under you, and start procceding along the learning curve, the game opens up and is quite exciting. I have been playing avidly for over a week now and I am still being amazed by the content I am discovering and starting to incorporate into my play style.  (ie farming coffee so I can go caffine crazy and sprint like a track star.  etc)Furthermore, it should be mentioned that when creating custom worlds to play in the user can extinsivly customize the game settings, tailoring the game to whatever is more entertaining for their particular play style and interests.  (ie I have a friend who doesn't enjoy survial games, he plays it as just a FPS zombie horde slaying, exploration game.)In conclusion, this game brings together aspects of a lot of games, in one package that functions quite well and provides a challenging, immersive, custimizable, and extremely fun experience.  Expect to find your self playing this game significantly more then you may of anticipated. I sure have!

								In the long line of survival games mushrooming up nowadays, this one really gets it right!There is nothing that makes a zombie game more stupid than stupid zombies.....   DayZ?  => Nobody is even looking at the zombiesRust?  => They removed them... and not too soonMinecraft?  => Known for the almighty Creeper.But with 7d2d you'll find the definition of Zombies that you are looking for. Still, even in its current state it is already a game that will hook you to your pc for days and have you looking forward to every future update.If you like this genre, this is definetly worth your time to check out.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having used to being a heavy gamer in my younger years before growing up like we all have to do eventually and taking on the responsibilities of a working life i wanted to still be able to have a lil gaming session from time to time but finding an appropriate game that could be played here and there and picked up from where i left off was hard to come by. I wasnt very knowledgable with sandbox games and how much fun they can be. If you are the type of person like myself with a busy personal life but seeking a game that is challenging/easy going (subject to your game set up options) alot of fun and prefer to enjoy coop with friends than online inc pvp then look no further. Having the freedom of doing whatever you want to the environment and building bases to survive, looting, crafting, messing around with friends for giggles and having to look over your shoulder from zombies especially during the night then this comes highly recommended. We all seek different needs from a game and i am easily satisfied with one. With the randomly generated worlds coming in one of the next updates this game is always going to be fun for me personally and others who enjoy this sort of thing. You can make the game as hard as you want or as easy as you want with the ingame options but may have to do a little bit of trial and error to find the most enjoyble setup. If anyone is considering this game but not sure then feel free to message me for any advice or want to know more before buying it in the Alpha stage.  Happy gaming ladies and gents.

content:
27, 2016
Early Access Review
Hard facts after 770 hours of gameplayI gotta say that this game is not what i payed for and changed a lot mostly to the worse. It used to be fun but it becomes more and more of a ridiculous grindfest and if u have a job or you study but want to get far in the game then forget it... (i played in a group of 4 and it was still just lots of grinding with no end)The developers try to force you to spent more time in game by making simple things more complicated with every so rare patch instead of actaully adding new content to the game that would keep u busy on advanced stages. On advanced stages its exactly as boring as it was, now it will just take you longer to get there.. trough lots boring and time consuming endless grinding...Terrible , lazy solution if you ask me.PROS:Great Building aspect.CONS:- Object/Weapons textures could be way better i mean even the original not HD Skyrim was better and that game is like what 3-4 years old now?The landscape textures are just bad, but they added HD light effects? set your priorities straight...Sound quality is super cheap. Game performance is poorly optimized if you can talk about optimization at all.-Glitchy graphics like see trough ground textures. You may eventualy fall trough such a glitch into a endless fall.Glitching terrain textures which will form some awkward shapes and block your path so you could even get stuck in them.-Glitchy zombie animations (which can get you killed)-Lags ,many lags, even if your machine fits the optimal requirments or is above.- Finding a decent community is very hard. - Too many hackers and no decent protection to keep them out.- Leveling... Well this is the worst level/upgrade system you ever saw besides of the fact that it kills immersion and dances on its grave, It just feels not realistic and annoying as if it was pushed in just to exist because hey all other games have that so lets kinda have one too.All the drops are now level adjusted says you have no chance of getting any even partly decent weapon/tool. It sells it self as a realistic survival game right, says it depends on scavenging and looting for things which will help you to keep the fight and stay alive... those are things which depend on luck , you should be able to find something great or trash... here you will find only trash till you get to a higher level no exception.	 Where is the thrill of what is in the next house im going to loot? What keeps me motivated to go on? 20 more levels of trash and no hope? probably not. -Extreme time consuming farming for resources. I get it here they wanted to make it suddnly more realistic on this part right? And they did it, exactly on the spot where no one would like it to be.I mean did i buy a mining or wood chopping simulator and didnt know it?If i would love to spent hours and hours on braking stone and chopping wood i could as well just go outside now and do it in real life.Immersion is great but not in everything.- Bugs spawn endless stream of hordes for several days which will ♥♥♥♥ your base.At this moment kiss your ammo good bey (which is hard to get) not only because the hords will really not end but also because now you will miss your target even if you aim dead on.Why? Because you dont have the skill points spent on this type of a weapon.... and that is supposed to be a ego shooter? a game where your true aim doesnt count for sh*t? -You will spent most of the day just eating and drinking or searching for food and drink. There is no end to your thirst and hunger.- Now the furnace takes like two hours or so (real life time) just to let you use the resources u grinded hours for already.And that is only for you to be able to start crafting and that doesnt include the long crafting times yet.- The weapons and tool crafting system is insanely bad, back in time you would have to advance from wood to iron to steel as far as you would get those... now u have to level up tool smithing to insanity just to get a dam pickaxe which will not break after some couple of hits. I dont start on the guns. - Devs dont listen to the community and seem only to fix things which are ultimatly game breaking while closing eyes on other known bugs.- Fixes take too long or dont happen in some cases, even though they tend to releas some hot fixes after every patch there are too many bugs which survived over a very long period of time.- I see no new content for almost a year and god this game lacks on that.And when they do add some little new thing to the game, that thing is going to be bugged!like those mini bikes,that took you hours maybe days to put together and would glitch trough the ground on your first ride saying bey bey. just one of many examples.-PvP is crap. Besides the hackers that will destroy your base no one can raid anyone! Because of the land-claim block which makes buildings indestructible.Again one point where they need more immersion but hey stone chopping realism was top priority i guess so they had to leave the less important game aspects out.I could go on for a longer list but i think this is enough info to form a opinion on the product. Its very sad how they keep ruining this game. And by now the game it self looks like a dead end. Sadly i see no future for this project, I would be happy if they would prove me wrong though. Do i recommend this game? No, definitly not anymore!I would strongly recommend to not buy it at the current stage.

content:
y 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love this game. It's still in Alpha, but playable with a few bugs (sniper rifle).I would compare this to a L4D2/Minecraft combination. With that being said, the game can get frustrating at the begining, but once you have a system down it becomes less frustrating and more resource stockpiling. In that it is a combination of those games, you will see alot of enemies that are very simular to L4D2 enemies. Cops are almost identical to the Spitter in the series. A few enemies are quite unique and can be a headache while trying to gather equipment. The idea you have to build everything is quite simular to Minecraft, except the list of available items to create and thier plans are all right there, removing the need to go wiki to look up ingredents.  The game does last longer than 7 days as a contridiction to the title, which is nice. There are many different options when starting a game. From single player to multiplayer, random map or Storyline map. The options of what happens to your gear when you die, how often items reset, how often airdrops happen, and even the legth of each day (way awesome). Some very interesting ideas that the game does offer is the ability to become infected, suffer from injury and disease, and attract zombies with some of the items you can have in your inventory. The ability to go into "sneak" is almost exactly like Skyrim, to include the HUD icon.The multiplayer portion of this game is what seals it down as a great game. When set up right it makes things interesting for a 4v4 multiplayer map as teams can fight over resources in an area, all while also trying to keep from being killed by zombies.  The down side to this game is that the crafting time can be really long and some resources aren't easily available as fast as you will go though them (brass and gas). If you don't have a good balance of difficulty you can find yourself spending your time just grinding with little to no challange. Tips: Leave your zombie run to Default, set your bag to "delete" when you die, and set your day/night ratio to 50%.

content:
y 7
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								I didn't think I would like this game as much as I did. 90+ hours later and I'm still playing it. To be honest, without the 7th night horde it would be a little boring, but because of it you are constantly repairing and planning for the next 7th night, so you always have something to do. However, there are some problems that are annoying, like: Terrain missing/stretching/glitching and falling through the world.Floating chunks of land that keep expanding in size that will break both of your legs if you run into it at the wrong place.Unforgiving desert heat, even with no clothes on and using the cool tea drink.Running on the minibike and glitching out to the point where you are warping around the map.FPS drop on zombie spawns.No minimap overlay, so you don't see where you are driving unless you hop off to check the map.Random landmines in places where they shouldn't be.Overall it's an addicting game if you have the company of some friends. Seeing as it's still in early access, some of the things I mentioned above might be fixed/changed or added :)

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
ry 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok ill be the first one to say that when i first laid my eyes on this game i was like "whoaaa.... L4D made sweet love to Minecraft and a loveable baby called 7D2D was born". I bought the game imediatelly without even thinking twice about it (Yeah, im that st00pid).I started playing it and i was like "Oh come on, this thing sucks so bad it could be an industrial vaccuum..." Graphics were terrible, controls were clunky, weapons were unfair (You would get weapon magazines by the dozen with each killed Fatty) and building was very limited... i was disapointed... i was crying on the inside to find out that the baby was actually a deceiving little sh*t faced a$$hole. I never touched it again but i still kept an eye out for it. It payed off, recently this game had just had a total overhaul so gigantic that it would make plastic surgeons around the world blush.I started playing it single player at first and i was freakin amazed on how the game changed... it looked like and entire different game altogether. Loved every single aspect of it... Combat was more fluid, melee weapons were awesome, firearms were somewhat rare and ammunition was even rarer. Single zombies are unthreatening and kinda funny actually but should you get overwhelmed, they will be the ones laughing over your pathetic corpse. Oh, you WILL die, thats for sure... Maybe not from zombies, maybe not from disease and even maybe not from a hidden trap... You will probably die while mining or while attempting to explore an unstable building. I built a freaking castle from concrete and reinforced concrete, complemented with forged Iron Walls and a huge moat filled with wood spikes and log traps. I had 2 Sniper Towers fitted with trap doors and a damn living room each with TVs, a fridge and other things totally (not) necessary for towers of death from afar... When i finished it, i went outside, looked up, puffed my chest and thought to myself "I'm an epic genious and i am teh bestest builder in the game"The i remembered i was playing a single player game... "Oh f*** "THERE WAS NO ONE TO SEE MY MASTERPIECE AND I COULD NOT MEASURE THE SIZE OF MY E-PEEN!!!! D:"PS: Don't play it alone Playing it with friends in controlled server (modded) is the best thing you can do. Don't play this game single player, you will quickly get bored of it and you will end up resenting it. No, best way to play is with friends/family and with voice chat to make things even better.PROS:-Massive maps that will take you literarly days to fully explore.-Very mod friendly game, you can find tons of mods to suit your gamestyle.-Melee Combat very intuitive and fluid, easy to master.-Ranged Combat is all about you... if you can aim, you can hit.-Crafting is now user friendly, showing the materials you need even when you dont have them in your inventory.-Intricate Wellness system adds to the survival mechanism, understanding of this system is a must for survival.-The sheer amount of customization makes building the best experience in 7D2D.CONS-Well, the biggest con is that this is a multiplayer game... there will always be people dead set in screwing other players over, no matter what. This isn't a con from the game itself, its from being multiplayer. Playing in a private and/or controlled server is the best you can do to prevent less reputable people from screwing you and your friend's fun.-Allthough this isn't really a con, the game is ruthless and merciless towards new players, making some of them cry like little girls... trust me, i know...-It's still an Alpha early access. (Not really a con, more like a reminder)-There are a few known major bugs that can be a pain in the a$$ but some of them can be bypassedBug 1: Sometimes when mining or jumping in a placed frame, you will fall through the map... yeah, kinda sucks but can fixed by leaving the server and reentering it.Bug 2: Disconnecting (wether by choice or forced) while crafting something in your crafting window will cause the materials and finished products still in collect slot to disappear, thus losing everything you were crafting.Bug 3: Sometimes when cooking food/drinks and/or using chemistry will cause the materials to completelly disappear without crafting anything.These are the major bugs known in the game (A10.4 at the time of this review). If you keep in mind one of these might happen, you won't be surprised and it won't ruin your fun as much. A11 is about to land bringing us weapon rarity grades, a Minibike (HELL YEAH!!!) and a new engine that makes GFX even moar sweet.So yeah, would totally build another fortress in single player... 10/10

ber 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Live in an Apocolyptic Landscape in which the dead roam the Earth.7 Days to Die is a Survival Horror in which you must survive by scavenging for food, water, supplies and weapons as well as fending yourself off against the undead by yourself or with other people. The world is fully interactable being that you can not only build new creations but you can destroy the landscape or go mining in the middle of nowhere. The Game also features a Creative Mode where you can build creations without it being overrun by zombies so you can build to your hearts content as well as use any item in the game.This is very fun to play with if you like to play these types of games or just want a fun sort of realistic zombie game, i definitely recommend getting some friends as it can allow for some fun that is depending if other people in the game will cooperate or become bandits and becomes a game of every man for himself in this apocolyptic world.Since this game is in early access there are alot of bugs, visual fixes and many things need to be added to make the game be more fleshed out but for what it is now is greatly fun.8.5/10

I can't wait for more from this game.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is quickly forming up to be one of my favorite zombie apocalypse/survival/crafting games. Earlier I was put off bit by the blocky terrain a'la Minecraft, while other graphics were aiming to some sort of "realism"(as realistic a zombie apoc can be) and now that the terrain is smoothed out, the game seems visually more in balance and it's easier to focus in crafting and everything else that happens in game.As a survival game, you are pretty dependant of your own skills - ability to create, build, defend and fix. You can head out scavenging for supplies and weapons, making a home base in existing buildings or start fresh, pick your own spot and start creating your own new base, just the way you like it.Majority of the game's items can already be crafted yourself and I believe eventually everything will be craftable. Every item and building block has it's own mass and durability. That determines how easily a zombie can bash through different types of wall materials and defences. It also determines how many building blocks you can stack or build in air without proper support before it crashes down. For example, a concrete roof will keep it's form under a heady load, while a scrap metal roof is likely to fall down if you walk on it.The zombies in 7 Days To Die have a short memory span and can follow you for a moment, even if they don't see you. If they can't see you, they will eventually forget you and you can try sneaking away. The Zeds also have great hearing and sense of smell, so carrying raw meat (or eating dog/cat food that causes gas!!) can cause problems if surrounded by living dead. And no, mining a new basement floor on urban areas isn't a smart idea.Currently it feels like the game has more than enough to keep me and my friends occupied for a long time, though I can't wait for the next major patch (alpha 9) that will include some AI tweaks, randomly generated worlds etc.For an early access game, 7 Days To Die offers a lot to do and has pretty good options to fine tune the game more into your liking. You can adjust the speed of time, the amount of zeds, AI skill, moving speed and threat, how often you get air drop supplies and so on.So yes, I do recommend this game. It's fun alone, fun with friends. I get huge satisfaction of locating the perfect base site, setting up defences and being able to survive night after night.
