content:
ry 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have had this game for quite some time but had not gotten around to playing it.    I kept checking back and reading reviews and forums to see how it was coming along even though I owned a copy.   I was waiting to see when it reached a point where family and friends might decide to dive in.    That point was reached a few weeks ago.I downloaded the Dedicated Server and fired it up in my house.   Myself and two of my sons jumped into it and spent A LOT of time dying.   We loved every minute of it.   We could immediately see it could be a challenge and it had a lot of things to do.    The effects of drinking unpurified water from lakes, rivers, etc and getting the little squatting and pooping icon in the lower left corner while you run around with the effects of diarhea is just one of numerous funny things.   However, the game is serious and even though that is funny it is a serious thing and is simulated as such.   It is only funny to realize the game simulates to that level and can be quite amusing.As this game is in early access it keeps getting better and better.    This is all my son, and wife have been playing for about two weeks straight now.   They'd put spikes strategically in river crossing points for zombie hordes, they've built towers for sniper posts, they've dug and built larger underground homes with large amounts of storage, they've established corn, cotton, coffee, potato, blueberry, and other farms near their location.They currently exploit a bug where if you are deep underground and stand close to a wall and look up it will clip and you can see the surface way above you and watch the hordes of zombies wander around.    This game is very stable from our experience, has a ton of features, and is for the most part bug free.    It has come a long way and can be a lot of fun.Also, if you've wanted a more co-op Zombie Survival game than the DayZ fare and don't really want to deal with the PvP aspects that is an option here.   However, it can be also run in the free for all style where newbs are fair game to camping  veterans who hunt them.    Our personal dedicated server this is not a problem and we just deal with surviving and exploring in the environment.It does have a standard map that it uses, but it also generates random maps that work really well.In this game surprisingly the DESERT biome is a nice place to be.   You can survive on Cactus fruit, and make Yuka Juice. :)   It has quite a number of Biomes.More realism is hopefully coming in the future such as greater thirst in deserts, and needing to have clothes or something suitable in the winter environments.   Those would be nice features.   They'd make the game harder, but that only extends its challenge and longevity.I very much recommend this game.For the Unity haters out there.   This game is made with Unity but functions very well.

content:
7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Friday 7 March 2014First off, I would like to say that this game was not always fun or playable for me. When I got it in Alpha 6 for $25 bucks, it took forever to load and initialize, the game lagged badly and frequently, and there were definitely some features, such as the random map generation mechanism, that simply were not there. My laptop is running Windows 8 with a 2.7 GHz AMD processor and 4GB of RAM, so lag should not have been a problem according to the posted game requirements. It made me upset, and I was very unhappy that I was unable to play the game I had just dropped $25 on. And then along came Alpha 7.The developers "crunched hard" on making Alpha 7 significantly better, and they kept their word to release it by the end of February. I logged onto Steam on February 28, and ---BAM-- there was an update for 7 Days to Die. It was about damn time for something to be done about the games' various bugs and alpha shortcomings.When I opened this game after the update, I was overjoyed to see that the lag problem had almost completely vanished, new items, patches, and options were in place, and that I could finally start enjoying the game. So far, I am loving every aspect of this game, especially the realistic strategy and tactics. One of my favorites is putting hub cap land mines in various clusters around a Survival Horde map. When they explode, they both kill the zombie that activated it, and draw all the other walkers toward the noise, away from me.I would say that 7 Days to Die is definitely worth the $25 I paid for it, although you might want to wait for a sale to pick this one up. Can't wait for Official Release!P.S.-If a developer is reading this:I would really like to see the random map generation feature released soon, so that by Alpha 8, we can all make unique maps to play on. That is the biggest thing that I absolutely can't stand about this game currently. Great game! Thanks for working hard to improve it.Update:Thursday 10 April 2014After the 7.9 update, I have to say I am rather unhappy with the current Co-op and Multiplayer abilities, but very hopeful for their future. Something this game seems to never be able to shake off entirely is its lag problem. If one update makes the game run smooth, the next may bring it back down to, make it worse than, or make it better than where it was originally. I know that the devs are working hard, as is evidenced in their persistent updates.I will still recommend you wait for a sale (perhaps the Spring Sale in a week or two?) to buy this game, as $25.00 is kind of a lot for the game in its present state.Update:Saturday 24 May 2014It has been two days since the release of Alpha 8.2, and I am very impressed with the way that this game is maturing. It has certainly come a long way since I got it back in Alpha 6, and I believe it is safe to say that it will only continue to get better. Ever since Alpha 8, I haven't experienced any major lag, frozen screens, and glitching (except when I set off ~100 barrels of oil- then there's a few second's delay), and with the addition of land claim blocks to go along with improved co-op and multiplayer options, my private server is all ready to go for my friends and I. I really like how you can get a potentially deadly 4-stage infection now if you are attacked by the undead, and require appropriate medicine (antibiotics) to save yourself, as well as the newly implemented clothing and armor system. Although I am getting a little anxious waiting for the random world generation option, I have to remind myself that I haven't quite explored all of Navezgane yet due to being occupied with building my reinforced-concrete-and-iron-bars bunker.Also just trying to survive in general now requires some effort, as I refuse to play on Beginner and Adventurer difficulty anymore---I am not saying that you are somehow a wimp or noob if you currently play with or prefer to play with these settings for whatever reason, but I have enough experience that I can now turn up the difficulty and have tons of fun, rather than die of starvation, zombies, radiation poisoning, thirst, etc., every 15 minutes, like I did for the first 5 hours of playing this game. Give it time, you'll get there, and then you'll have many hours of exciting and challenging gameplay ahead of you.

content:
er 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is by far the best in its genre.7 Days to Die is the perfect mix between crafting / survival and building / sandbox. The multiplayer is very similar to that of RUST or Day Z on public servers, with a much more intricate crafting and building system.7DTD is like a combination of everything good about Minecraft and RUST. It has a voxel based, infinitely generated world and block based building system similar to Minecraft, and a crafting system that far exceeds that of RUST. There are randomly generated points of interest, including many shops and stores filled with valuable loot. Three types of animals can be found (pigs, deer, and rabbits) and the zombies are plentiful and varied.The gameplay is multi-staged as you build and grow a base. Scavanging is essential to find food and water in order to survive another day, until you are able to start a farm for food. There are many different types of edible items, some of which give positive or negative buffs.The buff system is a masterpiece. Eating rotten food will lower your stamina temporarily, coffee can increase your stamina for a period of time, and zombies will infect you with enough damage. Antibiotics will cure your infection, but they are rare to find and hard to craft. Luckily it takes days for your infection to progress, up to three stages before you will die from it giving plenty of time to find that essential cure. Painkillers increase health over time as well as medical bandages, and a hit from an enemy can cause you to bleed out if you aren't careful.The penalty for death is extreme. Every time you die, your wellness is lowered by 10 points, meaning your maximum stamina and health goes down 10%. Wellness starts at 100 and goes up to 200, but for a new player this is a crippling handicap. Increasing your wellness is very hard to do, as the only thing that really helps is the very uncommon antibiotics. You can cook several types of items together into a pie that will increase your wellness, but during the early game without a farm this is an impossible feat, and the benefit is very small. If you are experienced enough to survive, increasing your wellness will double your health and prevent you from dying nearly as much.Every 7 days a super horde spawns, with many powerful zombies that will see you nomatter where you are. You can not hide, you can not run. As zombies run at night, having a base strong enough to survive their assault is required. Scavanging for and building guns and bullets to fight the horde is an intermediate skill, as you need to mine for coal and potassium nitrate in order to create gunpowder.Now that the positive things are out of the way, here are the negative things. As I'm writing this review during early access, please note that some of these things might change. First off, the wellness system needs some work. Once you die a few times it is nearly impossible to get back to full health. They have attempted to fix this by making it scale to your health, so the lower your health the more wellness you will get but at it's current stage it is still very flawed, and detracts from the game experience. This is especially important for new players, who will find themselves unable to damage zombies or sprint for more than 10 seconds at a time.There are still many glitches present, most notably the fireplace glitch. Sometimes when cooking large amounts of food or water you will lose everything. Occasionally you will duplicate an item. This is a serious glitch that I hope gets addressed soon. I have wanted to quit many times after hording enough food and water to survive, just to see it dissapear before my very eyes. If you have a full inventory, harvesting your crops will result in losing your crops, as harvested plants don't drop but instead dissapear. If you are crafting an item and log out, you will lose everything in your crafting area. This is very bad because certain items, such as TNT, take a long time to craft and you can forget that you are crafting them and log out, leading to a large waste of very precious resources. There are a few other glitches but none of them are noteable here.Another gripe I have is the lack of tutorial or information, similar to Minecraft. Almost everything in this game can be found by playing, but certain things like food recipes and controls aren't very obvious such as the RUST-like opening of doors and fireplaces. It would be nice if they added readable books in the environment to at least address this issue.Also the ingame voice chat could use some work as it does not seem to function well or at all, and communication in a game like this is absolutely essential.My final verdict is to BUY THIS GAME IMMEDIATELY. The develeopers The Fun Pimps are constantly updating this game with bug fixes and new features, but in it's current state it is well worth 30$. I Kickstarted this game because the quality was immediately visible, and it has now become the gold standard of early access in my opinion. I would strongly recommend that you play this with others as the difficulty is rather high, and building / defending a base with friends exponentially increases the fun. If you have ever enjoyed Minecraft, RUST, Day Z, or other similar games like The Forest, this game is a must buy.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
Early Access Review
								A work in progress that's starting to grow some moist, delicious meat on its bones. What started out as a basic proof of concept of another voxel crafting simulator with zombies thrown into the mix has slowly begun evolving into a realized apocalyptic world with meaningful danger, character advancement, useful and fun crafting, and looting that is neither lavish nor cruel. Though still lacking in any sort of narrative, simply surviving for its own sake can be an arduous--yet rewarding!--task that is made all the better with the inclusion of both singleplayer and multiplayer modes that allow co-operative and PvP styles of play. Your enemies are the omnipresent zombie menace, your own basic needs, and at your option and risk, other players, and 7 Days to Die has already implemented many honestly fun ways to deal with any of the three of these.This game is definitely still early access, though it is clear the developers are behind their game for the long haul, evidenced by frequent, meaningful updates. Bugs are as numerous as they are mild, with serious offenders being far in-between. Some recipies and features that are supposed to be there have yet to be added. There are as of yet no answers in the Navesgane wasteland as to why it is radioactive or zombie-plagued. That said, I welcome you to become a part of the early access development of 7 Days to Die, confident that if this game has piqued your interest, then there is certainly enough content to keep you entertained, and much more to come!Still not sure? Keep it on your wishlist. If nothing else, this is the game worth keeping an eye on.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Decided to give a little more of an indepth review since there doesn't seem to be many of them.1. Crafting:      - Building: You can craft pretty much whatever you want to build out of. Cobblestone, brick, prick paver for a pool, stone, whatever.      - Traps: You can also craft pipe bombs, sharpened sticks, land mines, use spider webs, anything to help fortify your hold.     - Food: Yes you can make multiple kinds of food though a cooking and items like gas cans through the chemistry system.      - Aestetics: What fun is the zombie apocolypse if you can't have pretty things in your house? You can now craft items (or steal them, and tv's/paintings from rich people), to decorate your house!2. Fighting:     - Players: ALWAYS fun     - Zombies: The way the game is set up the person who hosts (if they choose to host) gets to set the "difficulty" This is an actually impressive customized system. The host is able to set anything from zombies: How many zombies, how hard they hit, if there will be zombies at all (thats right you can turn off zombies and other enemies COMPLETLY if you just want a  pvp game) and if the zombies will run or not. It also lets the host decide how the day/night cycle is handled, if there will be more light than dark, etc. Also how many hits blocks take to break, and more. It lets you and your friends (or just you) have a customized experience. For added fun turn down the damage you do, increase the zombie health, make night predominent and turn on running. Oh and increase the spawn rate of  zombies by 200%, really, trust me,  it's so fun.     - Weapons: Many different types of weapons including guns (snipers rifle, shotgun, piston, machine gun), crossbows, melee weapons, or if you're feeling like just plowing through people, pull out a chainsaw or auger.3. Ambience: The background noise for this game is ridiculous. It actually has made me jump a few times. Nothing like being in the middle of a ruined city, hearing the wind blow around you and then..a baby's scream.This game updates VERY often, and really does listen to the community. The developers really seem to care about this game, and i've been very impressed with it so far. One of the biggest concerns I had with this game before I bought it though was the ability to play on a server with JUST my friends. This game lets one of your friends "host" a game and load up a server just for your friends, so have no fear! Also an added bonus is the fact you can CHANGE GAME settings whenever you load it back up. All your progress is saved AND you can change it. Finding zombies to much? Easy log out, reload and change it.

Early Access Review
								THIS REVIEW IS A REPLY TO ANOTHER REVIEW OF THIS GAME. WHICH I TOUGHT WAS UNFAIR. http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197999172691/recommended/251570/"Alpha 9 was the zenith"You mean back when you could rush in the city, get an auger and a sniper rifle (effectively ending the game) and be out before night fall? Not that nightfall mattered back then zombies were so slow and stupid it was too easy to kill them with any melee weapon.A9 was way too easy and became tedious much faster, now you at least have a sense of progression. You can't have everything you need in the first hours of the first day.Dog hordes on the 6th day: why not? Any half-competent player can deal with them with spikes or with a bow. I welcome those dog hordes it added a sense of urgency to what you did prior to day 6/7.Item quality was a GREAT addition, maybe you didnt read the dev's plan for this game but they always mentionned they wanted more RPG features. It prevents you from running into town day 1 and getting every weapon/tool you'll ever need. Gives a sense of progression. Only thing I agree with you here is the "forge ahead" book. But they removed that and made the recipe harder, which was a nice move."In my first few spawns on literally THE easiest, most bludgy settings that still involved zombies I died in under 2 minutes." Sorry but that's a l2p issue, dogs can easily be outrun and bears can be heard from miles away and give up very fast. No reason you should ever die to them.This review sounds like a lot of complaining for the sake of complaining, a lot of players have adapted their play style and love the new difficulty much more then before. Alpha 9 was the easiest alpha they ever released, it was a cakewalk and you were done with the game by day 7.P.S for all potential buyers, give it this game a try. It's only getting better and better despite what some players, who refuse to adapt, are saying.

content:
er 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								Firstly, great concept for a game. Love the mix of crafting with first person shooter aspects, along with the building physics which add a nice touch. Generally I feel a sense of desperation while I play it as zombies whittle away at my defences during the night and I have been scared ****less as those flying hornets that fly straight at my face. I find this game gives me a decent amount of enjoyment and is a good time killer.Unfortunately, these experiences are somewhat dulled down due to a clunky interface and fractured gameplay. This can be mostly forgiven due to it being in alpha stage of development so nothing is going to be perfect, however the price tag is misleading and gives the impression of a far more polished game. £22 is ALOT to be spending on an unfinished early access game, and does not match the experience and features that you will get. I understand that the developers may be looking to boost their funds to continue polishing this game, but £22 is a long shot for a game that has this many issues. I have to admit that if I hadn't seen youtubers play this game I would not have paid as much as I did, and if I had the opportunity now I would rather wait until later on when the game is more complete until I commit myself to buying it.So would I recommend this game? In the future, maybe. In its current state? Probably not. Although it is guaranteed to give you a few laughs and some enjoyment, I would recommend waiting to see how this game unfolds before you part with your cash.

number of helpful: 45 of 84 people (54%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
r 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing this game since the terrain was still blocks and "scrap metal" was a thing. That's why it pains me to say I don't think I can really recommend the game anymore. There have been a series of design choices that I just do not see as benefitial, and taken altogether, have been detrimental to the experience.Before I got to the biggest issue, first I should go into combat. I am not sure when it started, but combat has become annoying. Not for the fact it exists, but for the fact it often feels like zombies have a longer reach than you do, or that melee attacks you make against them that should hit do not. It feels like you must get much closer to them than they do to you. That on its own would be a fairly minor issue, however it does not exist in a vaccuum.All too often, you will be suddenly attacked from behind by a zombie that had silently crept up behind you from the surrounding area while fighting others. You are essentially expected to swing around mid-combat and scan behind you and your flanks to see if any other are encroaching. That is, quite frankly, ridiculous, nor from what I recall did it used to be that way. From what I recall, zombies used to make much more noise before, thus making it easier to notice them behind you.Again, on its own, too bad of an issue. So what is it that makes these problems such a big problem? Well, it's two-fold. Stunlock and "Wellness." When you are hit by a zombie, too frequently you are stunned. While you can still attack, it reduces more movement almost to nothing. While it may not sound bad to say "it only lasts two seconds," but that is two seconds where you are easily ravaged, quite possibly stunned again right after. That together with zombies that seem to have overly-long reach and can sneak up behind you without a sound, makes for a very frustrating encounter. And god forbid you die.If you did die, you encounter another major design choice that I cannot justify. The "Wellness" system. Your max health and stamina are tied to your Wellness, with a base Wellness of 100. A positive trend gives your more health and stamina, and likewise, a negative trend has a negative effect. And, apparently since Alpha 15, a new update at the time of writing this, experience gain is also tied to Wellness.Simply put, it is a semi-permanent punishment (there are ways to increase wellness) for not only dying, but for being attacked, or for being hungry or thirsty. To use a slight exagguration, you are punished for not playing optimally, by making it even more difficult to survive. You died? Then the game will make it easier for you to die again. Quite simply, that is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t considering, again, everything else I have said about the combat.With that out of the way, we come to what I think is the biggest problem with the game. The "7 Day Horde." Every seven days, a special horde will spawn nearby your location, or on top of you, and it always detects where you are at. The reason I consider this among the game's biggest issues is it essentially shuts down a nomadic style of gameplay, and it forces the game to be specifically revolved around this particular event, requiring you to establish yourself well enough to settle down and build enough defenses to stand against this horde. And that is all you are "allowed" to do. Any time you're spending not preparing for this horde is a waste, and in early game, could get you killed, which you are then punished for. This goes back to what I said earlier, where the game not only wants, but makes you, try to play "optimally," at least in the early game.Just take this recent example. I had a small house built, upgraded the lower portions to metal-enforced wood, and had my door upgraded. These zombies broke through the door within seconds, the zombie who actually broke it down took several headshots from a pistol, only for about four or five zombies barging in through the now-open doorway. Not to mention how totally useless my wood spikes were in that scenario, considering zombies, in general, seem to be attracted to breaking doors. How am I expected to defend against such aggression in so early of the game, only to be punished for dying? Especially considering you have to explore the map for resources, which takes away time that can be spent working on your base. The simple answer is there is no balance to these hordes oncesoever.And unfortunately, the developers have expressed refusal to make an in-game option for this 7 Day Horde, expressing that it is easy to to alter an XML file to turn them off. Frankly, it should be an option, and their unwillingness to do so under an excuse of how easy it is to edit a file, or as some people have argued, "people want options for everything," are just that; excuses. It is a foundational core element to the gameplay now, one that did not used to exist. Thus it is most certainly justifiable to have it as an option.There are other problems with the game that, while small, make for an overall inconvenient experience. The removal of the minimap and hunger and thirst bars on the player's UI, in spite of the fact that the map can be accessed at any time through a hotkey, and hunger and thirst can be seen on the character's inventory screen. Why these are not easily visible on the UI any longer, as they once were, I just cannot see a good argument for.The means of crafting was changed, from a Minecraft-like item-patterns on a crafting grid, to a more generic "select from a list." This change in itself isn't an issue, as even before,  you could select from a list and have items auto-placed, however with this update, the menu UI was changed. This is a visual matter, as the earlier inventory screen had a fitting design and aesthetic, while the newer one is bland and without any real asthetic, simply being a very basic menu over a grey background. Even the health and stamina bars look like they'd belong more at home on Microsoft Excel.Overall, while the game isn't terrible, it's presence isn't exactly strong, either. You might find it entertaining enough to justify its costs and compensation over its issues. If you have the money easily available to spend, and you think you may like it, then I suppose try it. However, I personally cannot recommend the game anymore; it simply has too much wrong with it, too many inconveniences, and that is really such a shame.

Early Access Review
The following is my thoughts on the game after 80.2 hours of playing, current version alpha 11.3 (April 26, 2015)I haven't been playing the game that much nowadays but still enjoy starting a new game whenever I marathon a bunch of podcasts. It's a great game to mindlessly play at low difficultly settings while listening to some crap. ;)The game has been updated frequently and now has some real good looking graphics after updating to Unity 5. Along with the updated graphics comes optimizations. I never get low frames that much anymore even with maxed settings.Still a great game to play.The following is my thoughts and experiences of the game after 48.7 hours of playing alpha 8 through 10.4 hotfix.  (December 21, 2014)My experience has been a little less enjoyable after playing for so many hours straight. Hordes spawn too fast with as much as only 2 minutes between horde attacks even when the game is set to low spawn rates. It's only day 3 on this new world, I don't think they should be coming this fast. But I guess that just adds to the challenge that many say is the proper way to play the game. The game's unoptimized state has never really bothered me that much as I was always able to maintain a good 60 in nearly all parts of the map with settings turned to low or off. The city was where it'd some times drop to 50 and below. But with how fast these hordes are spawning my fps frequently dips to <30fps while they're around making the game stutter and hard to defend against attacks.Even with these issues I'm still going back to the game multiple times a week. It's great watching the game slowly take shape with each update from the dev team!The following is my thoughts and experiences of the game after 22.8 hours of playing alpha 8 through 10.1.  (November 30, 2014)I like it.The reason I had any interest to pick up this game was because of the Game Society Pimps and their videos. If not for them I might of just passed on this game.This is a very fun open world sandbox zombie survival game. It's fun playing with your friends.There are bugs and it's not optimized but as it's still in alpha and these problems should be resolve by the time the game is done.PS - I had a pretty sweet underground base.

content:
er 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Edit :  For those who crack up laughing everytime they  see a negative review from someone with 1800+ hours sunk into the thing, please read the entire review :)Back in the days, before they lost it hard in the last couple patches, i would have recommended this game to anyone, but now, in its current state , i wouldnt recommend it to my  worst ennemy.First of all, this game as THE WORST pvp of all the survival games out there. There are SOOOO many glitches and broken stuff that you can do to enter someone elses base .For example, You can jump 13 blocks away ( yes 13 blocks) if you build wood frames up  to the sky limit  and jump down 200 feet , and you only get a broken leg and lose around 40 hp , dumbest thing i have ever seen in a survival game. You can also dig a hole in the dirt, place a ladder and then see everything underground, all the bases, the players and you can even shoot them :/. You can also dupe stuff, and trust me, every ♥♥♥♥ing noobs out there dupe a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of ammo and guns without working at all. those bugs have been here for a while now, and the devs dont do anything to correct it, so if you want a pvp survival experience, go look somewhere else, realy.Multiplayer lags alot, no matter the rig you have or your internet connexion, its just bad, if your ping is higher than 50 or 60, and theres more than 8 players on the server , expect lag. And the map is so huge that if you play pvp with 8 players or less you will probably never see anyone.The worst part tho is that there is  a stutering problem since alpha 11 ( around a year now), alot of people are complaining on the forums about this problem, the devs  aknowledged it, but even tho this is the most anoying and fun breaking bug i have ever seen they didnt do anything about it so far, even after a year of people complaining (most of us actualy stoped playing since its annoying as hell). i have a gtx 970, an i7 950 3,07hz which is old but still decent, 12 gb of ram and an ssd, and i still spike every 3 or 4 seconds when i run around, which is horrible, and other players with a  better rig then me lag too so its not computer related its in the game itself, go check out the forums to learn more.This game could be amazing, it used to be, but now its simply broken imo and yes this is alpha, but its been alpha since 2014...THis game still has alot of good sides, the cons just outweight it right now The building and crafting system is great, it might be a bit overwhelming at the begining but you have ALOT of choices. Graphics are much better and much more realistic than minecraft, and theres gravity, so you need to place pillars, doors, windows and stuff strategicaly, you can make some pretty complex stuff.It can be realy challenging if you max out the difficulty and theres some servers who made it even harder. Every 7 days there is a red moon during which zombies come at you all night long, wherever you are, they find you ( except if your deep underground maybe). Alot of people leave and rejoin during the day cause they cant handle it lol.The skill system is great too, if you play with friends you can each specialise in something in particular (tool smithing, weapon smithing, mining tools, guns, quicker crafting, workbench, concrete mixing, and much more)The game itself is awsome, i love it and as soon as they fix the stuttering problem i will play it again.But right now, even tho im a huge fan of this game, the stuttering makes it unplayable for me no matter the graphics settings i choose ,even when i put it at its lowest i stutter, and it looks like a god damn nintendo 64 game, i mean WTF, i can play any finished game on ultra settings ( shadow warrior 2, fallout 4, skyrim, and more) and even tho you cant compare an alpha release game and a polished game, if its not playable on the lowest settings even with a decent rig, then its ♥♥♥♥ing broken IMO.

er 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is trash, even if it was free to play you'd feel like you've been ripped off. It's hard to believe that a game with graphics this bad can run so poorly. Even if the terrible looking enviorment and zombies don't bother you, the unstable framerate is ridiculous.The combat system is garbage, probably the worst hit detection I've ever seen in a first person game. A zombie can strike you from 2-3x their arm length. You'd swear it's a latency problem but then you realize you're playing single player. Escaping from zombies doesn't seem possible anymore, they can spawn a few feet in front of you right out in the open.I didn't mind the incredible amount of time between updates when it was actually improving the game. The latest build however seems to have only added garbage that inconveniences you. It feels like 13 was thrown together at the last minute, not something that's been carefully planned out for months.Listening to the positive reviews for this game was a mistake I made. I understand that different people like different things, but some of the praise I've seen this game get makes me think these people have never played a basic survival game in their entire lives.I can't believe this game's price is near other EA games like Killing Floor 2 or Ark: Survival Evolved. This is likely the worst game in EA, it should never have made it through Greenlight.

er 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								It saddens me greatly to have to do this. I have been around this game since the days of alpha 8. However I cannot recommend this game in its present form. Alpha 13 broke so many things that didn't need tweaking in the first place. The crafting system is gone (it’s still there but is a former shell of itself) right clicking is gone to search is gone. The whole new interface practically slaps you in the face to break immersion it simply doesn’t fit. It looks like a computer interface it’s too clean almost if that makes any sense. the inventory interface doesn't feel like it belongs in a survival game rather then a down and gritty crafting aspect we are left with something that has all the recipes listed that you can just click on and it auto crafts them for you what did this need fixing ?. Zeds take forever to kill now, and can still hit you from 10ft away. The rate at which you get cold or hot is way off balance. Basically if you spawn in a snow biome or a desert biome you’re hosed. now on to my next gripe.  My system specs amd 8350fx asus rog am3+ mb 16gb g skills 2400mhz ram crossfired 7950s 500gb 10k rpm hd corsair h100i cooler1250 watt seasonic gold rated psu  Windows 7 I should have no issues running this game hell fallout 4 runs at 60+ on ultra with no frame rate issues. So why on earth am I having lag spikes and frame rate drops from 60 down to 15 in some areas for no given reasons what so ever. Tried with both video cards then tried with just one still the same thing. I understand this is alpha but hells so is ark and I still manage a solid 40-50 on that on ultra. I love this game i really do I like the concept and up until alpha 13 I loved where it was going. However in its present state I cannot suggest anyone buy it.

His fanboys are even worse, and it's frankly sickening to watch.So, why do I?Because the game, at its core, is really good. It is, and it has so much potential to get even better. If this was still A12.5 I'd recommend the game in a heartbeat. But right now it's just not fun to play anymore.I advice you to stay away until the game is completed and judge then if you find it interesting. You seriously don't want to participate in this particular development cycle.

content:
er 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Bought this as a bit of a gamble as I very rarely buy early access games and it was on sale.Best £7 I've ever spent. The game is hard to describe but it's like a cross between Minecraft, Left 4 Dead, Skyrim and State of Decay. You can craft weapons, armour, tools, clothes, ammo, medicine, food, water in fact practically anything in fact as long as you have the ingredients and the knowledge to craft the item. Some items you already know how to craft right from the start like a bow and arrows, boiled water and charred meat, others like steel you need to learn during gameplay.You'll start off in a "safe zone" where no zombies have spawned and it will stay that way for 5 in game hours (as of alpha 15). Use that time wisely to craft your starting gear which you'll find the ingredients for in your starting area, stuff like stone axes and plant finer clothes, a wooden club and a bow and arrows. This stuff is absolutely  vital to have before the zombies start spawning at 12 midday in your starting area and everywhere else once you leave the starting area.The game map is vast. It's made up of different areas know as biomes, they are pine forest, oak tree forest,  burnt forest, wasteland, desert and snow. The best ones for a noob are the pine and oak tree forest biomes. Avoid burnt forest and desert until you're more experienced apart from passing through or if you want some yucca fruit and aloe Vera plants which are in the desert biome. Avoid snow biomes due to the cold weather and lumberjack zombies who are very powerful when you first start.  Avoid wasteland biomes like the plague, this is the hardest area on the entire map, expect very harsh conditions,  very little plant life and a lot more zombies as well as the "special" zombies that spawn in the wasteland, you'll also have to deal with zombie dogs that can kill even an experienced player if you're not paying attention. You'll have until 10pm if you set the game to 18 hours of daylight before nightfall (highly recommended). During the nighttime you'll want to be inside a prefabricated building, on at least the first floor up and destroy the bottom part of the stairs. This is because at nighttime the zombies start running like in left4dead and can be hard to spot if you happen to outside at night. You can also make your own base but for your first night or two a prefabricated building is fine, just make secure it's secure. From day 2 or 3 though you'll need to start making your own base or fortify the prefabricated building you're in.So you're probably wondering why it's called 7 Days to Die? Well, on day 7 and every 7 days after that at nightfall (so 10pm on day 7 and so on) there will be a blood moon. You'll know it when you see it. You need to be in your base by 9pm at the latest otherwise you may get caught out by the lack of light or what comes next - a zombie horde. They will be running (unless you've set them to walk) and they can sense you no matter how well you hide (with a few noteable exceptions) so you'll have to fight them. They will also keep coming until dawn. Be prepared with plenty of arrows for your bow and prepare yourself by drinking and eating just before the horde arrives.Overall I highly recommend this game.

content:
er 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've struggled a lot with my opinion of this game because there are some *really* good things about it.  There are also some *really* bad things about it.At this exact moment in time, the good outweighs the bad.Pros:+ Crafting system is really polished.+ Progression from nomad to established base owner is fun, natural, and works really well with the game mechanics.+ Multiplayer with friends feels like a totally different game.  It can be an incredible experience with the right friends.+ Zombies are smart enough to pose a risk to the uninitiated, but dumb enough that you can fend off huge groups of them if you plan ahead.Cons:- Very poorly optimized.  I have an i7-4770k and a GTX 980 and running on max settings gives me 20-30 FPS with regular dips into the low teens.  I can get display-capped 144 FPS consistently on much more graphically-demanding games.- Bugs.  Dear lord, the bugs.  Expect things to randomly go missing.  Expect to die without any apparent cause.- The developers (and fans) seem openly hostile to bug reports or any kind of legitimate criticism of the game.  Its early access state is routinely used as a blanket apologetic for the game's problems.  Stay away from the game's official forums and subreddit.  They are both cancerous echo chambers.In summary: play it -- but go in with the knowledge that your experience will be far from perfect.

								This game is a great combination of mincratf-like games and fallout. I like that there actually is a danger out there and that your bases must be designed wisely. Getting the perfect base takes time, and you might end up losing everything after some weeks of surviving so the game is a constant challenge.The online gaming is great most players are nice and respectful, even on PVP, sadly the game seems to have poor security, cause twice in one day hackers logged in and screwed the game for some players. Losing everything to a horde or a fair fight with another player is ok, but spawning TNT through the walls is just frustrating, but that happens rarely and it's a very small minority of the players.Still a few lags and bugs, but nothing game breaking and very enjoyable during LAN parties. If they keep developping in that direction this game will stay awesome and get even better.The latest versions only made it better, the new skill system forces you you to cooperate with players and the new zombies make it a lot more dangerous and hard to survive. The challeneg keeps progressing and you have to keep evolving or be crushed byt the horde. I still recomment this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								After about 30 hrs. of play I can say this is my favorite zombie survival game. I have seen some reviews compairing it to Minecraft, they must have been a bit of time ago because the game has come a long way since then. The land and items are no longer blocky. Hills are a nice and smooth incline and you don't have to jump constantly to navigate it. The crafting system is great. Some things, like the stone axe (whice normally is the first thing / weapon / tool that you make) can be crafted from the onset of the game. Other items you have to find the recipie and learn it to be able to craft the item. There is also a time element in the crafting, depending on how complex the item depends on how long it takes to make it. The good thing is that if you need to craft a lot of something, like say arrows, once put the items in the grid and start the crafting you can close your inventory (which is where the general crafting grid is, there isn't a crafting table) and the items will keep crafting. It's great especially when you have a group of zombies on your tail and you run out of crossbow bolts. There are several forms of crafting in the game but I will let you figure those out.The zombies, in my opinion, look and act pretty darn good. There is a nice amount of zombie models and they look good. What might put some off is that even though there are a good amount of different models of zombies, each specific zombie looks the same. The big fat zombies look all the same, no variations. That is no big deal to me, the rest of the game more then makes up for it. The zombie animations are good as well. Sometimes they might act a bit wonkey when traversing an obstical, like when they are stuck in a spike trap they have a tendency to hop and hop. They are creepy as hell when you have a bunch of them shambling towards you and completely terrifying when they are running straight to you (if you have them set to run) with arms out stretched. If you do have them set to run at certain times of the day, the game gives you a great sense of urgency. You know you better be inside somewhere before they start running because you will be dead if you don't, unless you are armed to the teeth.The devs are great. If the community askes for something, they try to put it in. If the community then decides they really don't like the change they take it out. I have never had the oppretunity to talk with the devs, but everything I have seen on the fourms shows that they listen to what the community.This is my first review and I hope that it has helped some. If you are still on the fence check out some reviews or let's plays on your favorite video site. But if you like zombies, get this game. If you like crafting, get this game. If you like getting the ever lovin crap scared out of you when you are holed up in the attic of a house and the zombies are outside tearing the house to pieces and you know any second the house is going to collapse, then GET THIS GAME!!!!

content:
6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly good... I was really sceptical at first, but as one of my friends gifted the game to me I would loose nothing by trying the game. After seeing trailers and screenshots, my expectations were incredibly low, but after the first 5 minutes the game grew on me. the Atmosphere reminds me of Fallout 3 and the game world is incredible. This game is more akin to Minecraft than anything else. The vast amount of content and the satisfying gunplay keeps me going, and I LOVE the RPG elements... I am a sucker for exp and leveling. There are servers online which you can join for PVP but the most fun I've had is playing solo or co-op with friends. Your character, which you can make any way you wish, is saved as a profile to be loaded in different worlds (no items and levels transfer, only appearance). Crafting and building is extensive. Mining far into the ground and exploring underground caves is just as much fun as exploring the huge cities. There are many blueprints and schematics to find, and there are tonnes of ways to play. If you like survival games but want to stay away from all the hectic PVP, and just loose yourself in a postapocalyptic world, building bases and min-maxing supplies... then this game is for you. I give it an 8/10.

content:
5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Don't let your zombie apocalyptic dreams be dreams! Do it!- Stealth: Sneak past zombies undetected unless they see you.- Smell: They can smell the meat you carry. Cook to reduce stink range.- Sound: They can sense your voice chat if in range.- Running: The zombies run at night. Can be changed to always run.- Block physics: No floating blocks. No 'Redstone' yet.- Random map generation: New worlds.- Guns, traps and wandering hordes: Left 4 Dead & Plants vs Zombies defenseMinor issues: The default game settings are too difficult for new players. Probably need longer day time with lower damage zombies since you got stun in there already. And the automatic graphics settings detection seems not perfect in some cases even with friends' high end graphics card. It caused some weird glitchy bright images which would give the impression of the game as bad until the graphical settings got adjusted. But happy to report mine does not experience such problems.

content:
6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly good... I was really sceptical at first, but as one of my friends gifted the game to me I would loose nothing by trying the game. After seeing trailers and screenshots, my expectations were incredibly low, but after the first 5 minutes the game grew on me. the Atmosphere reminds me of Fallout 3 and the game world is incredible. This game is more akin to Minecraft than anything else. The vast amount of content and the satisfying gunplay keeps me going, and I LOVE the RPG elements... I am a sucker for exp and leveling. There are servers online which you can join for PVP but the most fun I've had is playing solo or co-op with friends. Your character, which you can make any way you wish, is saved as a profile to be loaded in different worlds (no items and levels transfer, only appearance). Crafting and building is extensive. Mining far into the ground and exploring underground caves is just as much fun as exploring the huge cities. There are many blueprints and schematics to find, and there are tonnes of ways to play. If you like survival games but want to stay away from all the hectic PVP, and just loose yourself in a postapocalyptic world, building bases and min-maxing supplies... then this game is for you. I give it an 8/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								After about 30 hrs. of play I can say this is my favorite zombie survival game. I have seen some reviews compairing it to Minecraft, they must have been a bit of time ago because the game has come a long way since then. The land and items are no longer blocky. Hills are a nice and smooth incline and you don't have to jump constantly to navigate it. The crafting system is great. Some things, like the stone axe (whice normally is the first thing / weapon / tool that you make) can be crafted from the onset of the game. Other items you have to find the recipie and learn it to be able to craft the item. There is also a time element in the crafting, depending on how complex the item depends on how long it takes to make it. The good thing is that if you need to craft a lot of something, like say arrows, once put the items in the grid and start the crafting you can close your inventory (which is where the general crafting grid is, there isn't a crafting table) and the items will keep crafting. It's great especially when you have a group of zombies on your tail and you run out of crossbow bolts. There are several forms of crafting in the game but I will let you figure those out.The zombies, in my opinion, look and act pretty darn good. There is a nice amount of zombie models and they look good. What might put some off is that even though there are a good amount of different models of zombies, each specific zombie looks the same. The big fat zombies look all the same, no variations. That is no big deal to me, the rest of the game more then makes up for it. The zombie animations are good as well. Sometimes they might act a bit wonkey when traversing an obstical, like when they are stuck in a spike trap they have a tendency to hop and hop. They are creepy as hell when you have a bunch of them shambling towards you and completely terrifying when they are running straight to you (if you have them set to run) with arms out stretched. If you do have them set to run at certain times of the day, the game gives you a great sense of urgency. You know you better be inside somewhere before they start running because you will be dead if you don't, unless you are armed to the teeth.The devs are great. If the community askes for something, they try to put it in. If the community then decides they really don't like the change they take it out. I have never had the oppretunity to talk with the devs, but everything I have seen on the fourms shows that they listen to what the community.This is my first review and I hope that it has helped some. If you are still on the fence check out some reviews or let's plays on your favorite video site. But if you like zombies, get this game. If you like crafting, get this game. If you like getting the ever lovin crap scared out of you when you are holed up in the attic of a house and the zombies are outside tearing the house to pieces and you know any second the house is going to collapse, then GET THIS GAME!!!!

content:
y 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've really been enjoying this game. For an early access game it's extremely entertaining, and has a lot of features, and constantly gets updated. As with early access games, it's lacking features or has certain gameplay issues. It falls under the zombie survival genre, with added aspects of crafting and building, and does all of those much better than similar games.The zombie aspect is very well done so far. The early game is very enjoyable and challenging. The hoards every 7 nights, as well as wandering hoards, keep more passive players challenged. High value areas with higher risk make the difficulty enjoyable. Different types of zombies make a much better zombie gameplay, though I really do hate the way dogs are. I find the current issue is being able to finalize a base and move into the late game. Going into the late game means there is very little challenge, as you've set up a fantastic base with access to many resources, and very low risk of ever being overrun, basically the zombie aspect becomes weaker. Leaving a crafting and building experience as the focus. As an alpha, that could very well be changed and would make this game even better than it already is. The crafting and building aspect of the game are decent so far. There are a good amount of block types for different stages of the game, and different types of buildings. Making a decent progression for base building. Crafting is done well so far, but I feel there is a lot of room for improvement. The RNG of needing certain books to unlock things can be very fustrating. Progressing with techology of tools and items progresses a little too fast, and slow, depending on the stage of the game. More depth would be very nice. Overall crafting and building are solid, but have lots of options and room to grow as alpha goes on.The issues it currently has are the very basic form of random generated maps, though it's a newer feature. There is a low number of Points of Interests / unique buildings. Though they are adding them regularly, and currently the core buildings are all great. I would really like to see a ton of new buildings combined with a better random generated system to make a better game. Regardless there has been good progression regarding this, and I have high hopes for the outcome.The game is not the most stable and plenty of people complain about fps drops around certain things, or with too many zombies. Though personally my pc is very good and handles it well enough. Overall this game is good with lots of room to become really amazing.

content:
y 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I am not often inclined to take the time to write reviews, but this game has shaken my apathy. I was intrigued by the trailer and when the game went on sale I bought it. I don't have a true dedicated gaming computer and I can't run the game on the high setting like you see on some of the YouTube videos of this game and I've never gotten my FPS past 30. That being said I love this game.       The up and down side of this game is that it does not hold your hand and tell you how to do anything. The first three days I played I spent in an adrenaline soaked fearfest. After spending the night crouching and doing nothing in my fortified prefab I made some sort of noise and within moments dozens of wicked fast zombie ripped the walls down and tore me to shreds. After logging off in a panic I went to various wiki pages and YouTube to educate myself. After learning the massive crafting system and the all important first day order of operations (check out Oak's Game Room 7 Days to Die tips and playthroughs) I have since been able to make it 7 days without dying consistantly. I have not played much multiplay and no PvP (for me the zombies are enough to think about, thank you) but I can see the draw, especially because once you've had a chance to make a base, mine ore, find and read the books, craft guns and ammo and stockpile food you become a stand alone army. You will go from hiding from the undead to carrying meat around to attract more, allowing you to further cull Zach's population. That chilling fear of ever present death will be replaced by the rush of power as you look down in complete safety as the undead rush toward your stronghold and kill themselves on your redundant defences, leaving you to tend your garden in peace.       Since the game is in Alpha (I started in 10.4) there are still some major changes coming down the road and a few bugs (very rarely crafted items will disappear from the crafting window if you search for something else), but the game is very playable and quite fun. There are plans to make a story with missions and so on, but there is none of that now and it is still crazy addictive. I would recommend checking this game out and helping the developers flesh out this game.

content:
29, 2015
Early Access Review
								So.... I might have put some time into this game so far. Almost entirely on random generated worlds- each start being a unique experience and extremely rewarding. I started with the basics and now I've modded just about every xml file to personalize the gameplay experience even more than the very thorough options they give you in the menu.My wife and I play on a custom server together (that was easily made in about 5 minutes) and we are honestly excited about every update and often check the dev blogs to see what is coming down the pipe. This is not a perfect game. Hell, this is not even close to the finished product they have promised. This is a game that is still in Alpha. But the thing about this game... it's so good and addictive despite the state that it's in and the updates ARE coming, and the development team IS  keeping an eye on the community's ideas and  complaints- that I have faith that when the finished product arrives it will be exactly what was promised. And more importantly, I'll be happily playing while we wait for that day. You may not want to put the money in on it today- I totally get that. But you damn sure want to follow this game so you don't miss the release and what looks to be one of gaming's finest moments.

content:
4, 2015
Early Access Review
Others have said it and I will say it as well: this game is the best zombie survival, open world crafting game ever made. Before I begin my review, can I just say - THIS GAME IS HARD WHEN YOU FIRST START OUT!When you first start out, you don't know what to craft. You don't know what specific survival actions you need to take to make life easy. So, you just run around like a chicken with its head cut off. And then you complain saying the game is hard. I put in 30 hours before I understood some of the basic survival mechanisms to increase my survival actions per minute.IF YOU'RE FRUSTRATED BECAUSE THE GAME IS TOO HARD, PLAY ON A PVE SERVER WITH LOW DIFFICULTY SUCH AS 3.Do NOT do PVP if you are frustrated about the difficulty of the game. Seriously. You are doing the game developers, the community and yourself a disservice. Stay away from PvP. It's not worth it. Once you've put in 30 hours on a PvE server, start on a PvP server with low zombie difficulty and high loot. This is what I am currently at and I love it.If you don't care about the difficulty and are willing to endure the learning curve against greater odds of difficult PvP, then by all means, knock yourself out.Part of what makes this game great is that its potential is actually getting converted to reality piece by piece with each patch (unlike other games we know of..) Also, the developers are awesome and connected with the player base and are determined to make it the best zombie open world survival game.>Crafting system? Awesome.>Fully destrucible / constructible world? Yep.>Want a scary, atmospheric environment where you could die any second from hunger, thirst or zombies? Yep.>Want to build a mighty underground kingdom that no one knows about? Go right ahead.>Want to build a great castle fortress above ground? You can do that - just be prepared to deal with the attention.>Want to build obstacle courses for zombies? You got it!>Want to play like CS:GO? Go right ahead. You will be known on the server as the local serial killer.>Want to play like a pirate without a permanent base? You can do that. Just write down the coordinates of your buried loot.>Want to play survival with your friends on hellish difficulty? You can do that. You better hope your friends don't tip off the zombies.>Want a server customized to your tastes and preferences? YES. This is actually freaking awesome.>Want to survive in a cold, snowy wasteland? You can.>Want to survive in a scorching hot desert with little water? You can.>Want to survive in a forest with wild boars and elk to kill? You can.>Want to construct base defenses (traps, thick walls, etc..)? You can.>Want to create hidden chambers and passage ways? You can.>Want to get in gun fights with other players? You can.Bottom line is, this game, even in early access, is incredible. Yes, it has some bugs. They're frustrating sometimes, but not game-breaking.

content:
er 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've struggled a lot with my opinion of this game because there are some *really* good things about it.  There are also some *really* bad things about it.At this exact moment in time, the good outweighs the bad.Pros:+ Crafting system is really polished.+ Progression from nomad to established base owner is fun, natural, and works really well with the game mechanics.+ Multiplayer with friends feels like a totally different game.  It can be an incredible experience with the right friends.+ Zombies are smart enough to pose a risk to the uninitiated, but dumb enough that you can fend off huge groups of them if you plan ahead.Cons:- Very poorly optimized.  I have an i7-4770k and a GTX 980 and running on max settings gives me 20-30 FPS with regular dips into the low teens.  I can get display-capped 144 FPS consistently on much more graphically-demanding games.- Bugs.  Dear lord, the bugs.  Expect things to randomly go missing.  Expect to die without any apparent cause.- The developers (and fans) seem openly hostile to bug reports or any kind of legitimate criticism of the game.  Its early access state is routinely used as a blanket apologetic for the game's problems.  Stay away from the game's official forums and subreddit.  They are both cancerous echo chambers.In summary: play it -- but go in with the knowledge that your experience will be far from perfect.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Bought this as a bit of a gamble as I very rarely buy early access games and it was on sale.Best £7 I've ever spent. The game is hard to describe but it's like a cross between Minecraft, Left 4 Dead, Skyrim and State of Decay. You can craft weapons, armour, tools, clothes, ammo, medicine, food, water in fact practically anything in fact as long as you have the ingredients and the knowledge to craft the item. Some items you already know how to craft right from the start like a bow and arrows, boiled water and charred meat, others like steel you need to learn during gameplay.You'll start off in a "safe zone" where no zombies have spawned and it will stay that way for 5 in game hours (as of alpha 15). Use that time wisely to craft your starting gear which you'll find the ingredients for in your starting area, stuff like stone axes and plant finer clothes, a wooden club and a bow and arrows. This stuff is absolutely  vital to have before the zombies start spawning at 12 midday in your starting area and everywhere else once you leave the starting area.The game map is vast. It's made up of different areas know as biomes, they are pine forest, oak tree forest,  burnt forest, wasteland, desert and snow. The best ones for a noob are the pine and oak tree forest biomes. Avoid burnt forest and desert until you're more experienced apart from passing through or if you want some yucca fruit and aloe Vera plants which are in the desert biome. Avoid snow biomes due to the cold weather and lumberjack zombies who are very powerful when you first start.  Avoid wasteland biomes like the plague, this is the hardest area on the entire map, expect very harsh conditions,  very little plant life and a lot more zombies as well as the "special" zombies that spawn in the wasteland, you'll also have to deal with zombie dogs that can kill even an experienced player if you're not paying attention. You'll have until 10pm if you set the game to 18 hours of daylight before nightfall (highly recommended). During the nighttime you'll want to be inside a prefabricated building, on at least the first floor up and destroy the bottom part of the stairs. This is because at nighttime the zombies start running like in left4dead and can be hard to spot if you happen to outside at night. You can also make your own base but for your first night or two a prefabricated building is fine, just make secure it's secure. From day 2 or 3 though you'll need to start making your own base or fortify the prefabricated building you're in.So you're probably wondering why it's called 7 Days to Die? Well, on day 7 and every 7 days after that at nightfall (so 10pm on day 7 and so on) there will be a blood moon. You'll know it when you see it. You need to be in your base by 9pm at the latest otherwise you may get caught out by the lack of light or what comes next - a zombie horde. They will be running (unless you've set them to walk) and they can sense you no matter how well you hide (with a few noteable exceptions) so you'll have to fight them. They will also keep coming until dawn. Be prepared with plenty of arrows for your bow and prepare yourself by drinking and eating just before the horde arrives.Overall I highly recommend this game.

content:
21, 2014
Early Access Review
								(See below for Update to review)Ok, I bought this game a while back and have been playing it off and on, almost with each update.  I have to say, that I am very happy with the latest update which provides random world gen instead of the default map. I have about 4 friends that make this game very fun to play since we can work and explore together. I think this game is worth every penny. I consider it like this. Look how much it costs to go to a movie..... Or even buy a good blu-ray.  Now consider how many hours that keeps you entertained.  Then consider that this game can keep you happy for even just a 25 hours (I believe it will be almost 200.) You can see that it is quite a bargain. Then on top of it, you can restart it with another random generation map and play again. How can you beat that?UpdateSo, now that I have almost 400 hours, I feel I need to update this review.I now believe that this is one of my favorite games of all times and I will list the reasons why.Positive reasons.1. This game provides a well balanced survival experience.  Food and water, shelter and defense.2. The graphics while not spectacular, are on par for a game of this much content in my opinion.3. This game does not force you to join a server with other players.4. This game can provide a single player, local LAN or even public server experience.5. The game has a wide variety of difficulty.  From almost too easy, to insanely impossible.6. Regular updates and news from the developers, as well as screen shots of upcoming content.7. Structural physics, no floating blocks or seemingly impossible constructions.8. New atmospheric conditions and weather system. I love it, adds a whole new level of "creepy" to the game.Wants.1. More animals - Deer, rabbit, pig, and bears.  I hope they put more into the game.2. More diversity in weapons - The guns are plenty diverse, but maybe a few more melee weapons.3. Travel options - Motorized bike coming soon, but maybe a car or truck too.4. More trap options, or possibly mechanized or spring loaded traps.5. Power - Electricity for lights, cooking, maybe an electrified fence.6. Objective oriented goals - Not necessarily quests, but some sort of goals other than survival would be nice.7. Leveling perks and possibly attribute points that affect combat, crafting, survival traits.Other thoughts.This game is well worth the price asked by the devs.  I believe that I have never had as much fun in any triple A titles.  I was lucky and got the game during a sale and to be honest, the sale discount they give is substantial unlike some other big name titles that only offer a 5 to 10 % discount and only that because it's been out for 2 years.Hope this helps make the decision for you.(Update November 2016)So, I have been playing this game so long now it should be obvious by now that I find the game worth it just by the amount of hours I have put into it. If that doesn't convince you, the just read my review above. I am a little disappointed that the Devs seem to be slowing down on developement here but I understand that it's not always easy to put in all the things you want to put in. It's still worth it's price in my view.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I do recommend this game.  ----First id like to start with the negative things though (i know its a bit backwards)The dev team can be kind of finicky at times, they tend to break things in attempts to fix it, only making things more frustrating. For example they took out the viability of melee combat in comparison to ranged, i dont know why because it was in no way overpowered as you still needed tons of meds and bandages. They do realize the issue ... but wont fix it for a very long time from now(alpha 13 to be exact). i dont know about you but melee combat not working in a zed survival game is really bad. HACKING it is real... and it is alive, i dont know what the devs are trying to do to stop people from hacking but it is bruuutal, your house, everything you worked for can be gone in the blink of an eye to a hacker so beware. An easy fix to stop hackers is to disable creative mode, i know a lot of creative people would be upset and all but us online players dont like getting hacked on(i speak for us all) .Other than that of course there are the usual alpha complaints, be ready to deal with constant wipes and at times stability issues, they are easy to overlook unless you are some architect that likes spending all their time on building something pretty. --- As for the positive, The game is pretty and is getting even better over time, the environments and the textures, variety of weapons and crafting. Its super fun especially when played with a good community or even just 1 friend. the variety is just so huge you never know what you are going to find. i do recommend playing it on hard or feral though or else the game is kind of too easy. The sheer potential of this game is enormous and with every large update you find yourself in a somewhat brand new game.           HAPPY HUNTING!!!PS. They added this thing called gore blocks recently and its god aweful and i hope they fix it, at first it made sense that zombies dead bodies could pile up causing others to use them as a +1 elevation platform, but the way the devs implemented it is poorly executed in my opinion.

content:
er 1, 2016
Early Access Review
7 DAYS TO DIEFirst off, this game runs like a Zombie. It's in early access and you will see odd things. I'm not talking about seeing Walking Dead, rotting corpse, dismembered body parts. I'm talking about early access bug issues and glitches. Nothing atrocious, although they are there and this leads to the graphics. The graphics are almost as bad as zombies themselfs. Graphics comparable to around 10 - 15 years ago.So what is the massive appeal with the masses?Gameplay.7 Days To Die has the most outrageous gameplay. You are thrown into a Zombie Apocalypse with nothing except boxer briefs and you must survive. By any means, SURVIVE.Basicly you begin as a Neanderthal and carry youself to modern technology by scavenging, hunting, crafting, building, etc, etc. All the while Zombies want to crash your party and eat your brains and THAT is what throws your game off.No matter what you are doing, you will be looking over you shoulder. You will be listening for that familiar Zombie moan. You will be watching the clock. (Don't stay out after sundown.) This all adds up to some intense surviving.How many days will you survive, before you die?

content:
r 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Best survival game I have played! So many possibilities, so much items! I love the crafting system, love the unlimited base building, you can even build under ground! I love that part so much, Alpha 15 just landed and I like the direction they are going! it keeps getting better, more items are introduced, content wise this game is perfect, BUT performance wise it is awful. It is sad that I can't enjoy the game due to poor frame rates... from 60 (v-sync on) it often drops to as low as 10.. In the cities I have stable 60 but in the forest only 10? where nothing is happening? That greatly impacts the enjoyment..6/10 those -4 points goes to performance.. content and gameplay are absolutely great.
